content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												(Disclaimer: This is a completely un-ironic and non-satirical review. Most of my other reviews are silly and are supposed to be funny, but this is a 100% true account of this video game.)I know that at the time of me writing this review, it says that I have barely any hours put into this game. This is true for the PC, as I just bought it on sale. However, already having 150+ hours on console, I feel that I can effectively write a review of this game. Brutal Legend has been, since I bought it in early 2010, one of my favorite video games of all time. I do not say this lightly; this game has touched me personally and changed me. This game introduced me largely to what i am today.First, a little backstory. I was blessed with a very musical family. Me, my brother, and my father all play instruments, and I have been around guitars and hard rock ranging from ACDC to Metallica from a young age. My parents are both fans of metal, and so from a young age, I listened to music like Iron Maiden, Motley Crue, and Dragonforce, just to name a few. One of the earliest band shirts I ever remember wearing was an Iron Maiden shirt in first grade.Video game have also been a medium for my family for years; we've had consoles ranging from the Saturn to the Dreamcast to the N64 to the PS1 to the original Xbox, and we still have a plethora of consoles to this day. I have always been a fan of video games, and luckily my parents don't mind what kind I play; in fact, some of my fondest memories were of playing Halo 2 system link with my parents in their room and me and my older brother in the living room (my father drilled a hole in our wall to make this possible).Anyways, shortly after the game came out (about February 2010) we went to Best Buy. I had some money left over from my birthday in January (I believe I just turned 11, and was in fifth grade), and I wanted to get a video game. The choice came down to Red Faction: Guerrilla or Brutal Legend. After carefully reading the backs, I decided I had to choose: destruction, or heavy metal? I ended up buying Brutal Legend; however, I did buy Red Faction a few months later.So I went home, and it being a weekend, I played the game for hours. I beat the game in a few days, but continued to play it for much longer. I believe that the last time I've played, I had every tab, and I know I had every upgrade. I beat the game on Brutal at one point. I believed this game was pure perfection. When I was younger, as I've said, I only really listened to some baby metal; this game showed me the wonders of different subgenres. I've come a long way over the years, all thanks to this game. I started out with bands like Dethklok, and now I listen to all different types of metal, with my favorite being Atmospheric Black Metal along the lines of Summoning and Drudkh. This game was the reason for all of this.Another amazing aspect of the game was simply the detail in the characters and the world. I found the game mesmerizing as a child, and believed it was hilarious; not just in the dialogue, but the depiction of the stereotypes. I remember laughing with my father as he expressed amazement at the fact that Lemmy, Ozzy, and Halford were in the game. I remember thinking it was the funniest thing as I reamed goth people in a car while blaring speed metal. I remember the depictions of Hair Metal kids as sellouts, and loving it. Understanding the references may not be hard, but for a fifth grader, it was liberating, finally being able to understand comedy.As for the gameplay itself, the game isn't that amazing. Basic combat and the clunky RTS elements make it a bit awkward, but the game more than makes up for it in sentimental value and world design. I eagerly, and relatively naively await the day that Double Fine announces Brutal Legend 2, despite the fact that it probably won't even happen. When it does, it will be among one of the games that I have preordered, a list that as of now only consists of Bioshock 2 (a severe disappointment in my eyes) and Dark Souls 2.In conclusion, Brutal Legend is an amazing game that has a special place in my heart. This review may not be too helpful, as I recognize the fact that it's all sweaty fanboy-ism, but I felt that I had to let other people in on a personal experience I've had with the game. If you are a fan of heavy metal, play this game. If you aren't a fan of heavy metal, still play this game, because the amount of detail and the humor are still enjoyable. Plus, maybe it could broaden your musical tastes and FORCE you to like metal! In any case, I cannot recommend this game enough. I have had more enjoyment with this game and hold it in higher esteem than any other, except perhaps Dark Souls. This game changed me as a human being, for better or for worse, and while it may not touch you in the same way that it touched a cringy antisocial preteen (THAT SENTENCE SHOULD NEVER COME OUT OF ANYONE'S MOUTH), you may still find some enjoyment in it. Hell, if you buy it on sale, you pretty much just spent three bucks on "Drive Around and Kill♥♥♥♥♥♥While Metal Plays Simulator". If you can't find enjoyment in that, I feel sorry for you.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												A game brimming with heart and style, lacking not in quality but in an identity and proper marketing.  Graphics and art style hold up today with every landscape, monster and toon serving as a gorgeous tribute to its subject matter.  Animation does get buggy at times, but seldom enough to rip you from the experience.The music and soundtrack for this game is exceptional for enthusiasts.  A solid variety of tunes from various genres of metal are sure to appease all but the most discerning of music palettes.  Voice acting is top notch for the most part, at least when it comes to the big name VAs.Story holds your attention.  It's not going to reverberate in your mind when you're done playing the game, but isn't so awful that it gets in the way of your enjoyment.  The humor and dialogue holds up alright, but again, won't win any awards.  Your love of the writing will likely be based on your love of Jack Black or the various musicians/actors who cameoed in this game.Where the game still falls short to this day is its attempt to make a console friendly RTS.  Controls are streamlined enough to only allow for the broadest of unit management.  Keyboard and mouse controls do help, but little effort was made to properly port this title to PC (game still uses a controller friendly radial menu for Solos and army building for instance).  This can sadly make some of the RTS segments feel like a grind compared to the action portion of the title, especially if you're struggling to get through a segment to advance the game.The action controls also sadly suffer in the PC port.  Having to hold a lock button down in order to dodge feels wrong, and not allowing the player to remap it as a toggle switch discourages its use entirely.  Futzing with the radial menu for solos will require adapation to feel natural.  Thankfully, mouse control for camera does alleviate some of the control issues with the previous game.  The driving also feels better in the PC port compared to the console.Online community has largely left this game, but the campaign and single player experience is certainly worth the buy in.  The map is impressive in size and hides all sorts of secret goodies that will have you hunting around for a good deal of hours if you're the completionist type.  Driving is a thrill and just cruising around the map while a favorite song plays on the radio can hold your interest.  Side missions give you lots to do, but it can get very samey very quickly (So many Ironheade sneak attack missions are the exact same setup).  The game gives you plenty of fire tributes (in game currency used to purchase upgrades), so you can thankfully cherry pick those mini games that appeal to you, or simply harvest them from the collectibles.Sadly, because the online community has left, you're opportunities to play as the other factions within the game are limited principally to AI skirmishes.  Bugs do creep up from time to time.  Minor visual bugs can take you out of a cutscene, but haven't yet cropped up during gameplay.  Game has crashed to desktop on me once, but no progress was lost due to rigorous auto-save system and being fortunate enough to not be on a mission.  Moving in and out of the map and menus can also be an inconsistent experience (sometimes pausing the game, sometimes not).Despite my issues with the game overall, it's still very playable.  It is both a tribute to metal while itself being a work of visual and auditory art.  If metal music or culture are of any interest to you or if you ever wanted to try a game that's a chunky blend of God of War, Grand Theft Auto and Dawn of War, this game is worth a purchase.  Those seeking a competitive RTS experience should look elsewhere.

												A crazy and unique open-world, action, adventure, and real-time strategy game.  That's right... it even has RTS game-play that was modeled after the amazing Sega Genesis classic Herzog Zwei.  There is quite a bit of depth to the RTS with lots of different unit types and the ability to control where each group of units go on the battlefield.  Some of the RTS battles were very difficult and I had to replay them a couple of times, and each time could be a half hour or more.  I changed the difficulty level to “gentle” so I could get past some of them.  In addition to the RTS battles, there are missions to rescue people, escort the tour bus, and racing sequences.  There are also lots of side missions.  The story is fairly complex and interesting and is told with a lot of humor.  If you like Heavy Metal music it has a great soundtrack and cameo appearances from several famous band members.  Overall it is a fun and unique experience that should not be missed.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												This game is just another title from Double Fine. And we all know that that means...There are three qualities to this game that make it worthy of the hype it has gotten. For Simplicity's sake, I'll label them.It's true to the source material.This is suprising since the source material is just Metal. Metal songs, and metal cover art, and that's it. Now drive around the land that the game takes place in, and tell me that you can't take a screenshot of ANY LANDMARK, slap a random cover title on it, and tell someone that it's a real CD cover. This is quite spectacular, but it's nothing for Double Fine. They seem to specialize in surreal locations that others couldn't imagine existing. They made Psychonauts, after all. They also use metal instruments for all background songs. ALL OF THEM. (Sadly, you won't hear it that often because you're too busy listening to the 107+ metal songs on the radio in your car) If you are a hardcore Metal fan, you won't be disappointed.Characters applenty.As a Double Fine game, it makes sense that every character has lines for any situation that they can get into in game. Your allies sees Eddie play a song? Compliments come in. They see Eddie take off? They can say that your wings look cool, or tell you not to leave them, depending on the circumstances. Also, the commentary is hilarious. The guy that takes the case though, is Eddie Riggs, the main character, who is voiced by Jack Black (the voice behind Po in Kung Fu Panda, among others). He takes the cake by staying true to the character of a Metal Roadie thrusted into the world of Brutal Legends, all the while showing off his incredible comedy skills.Real Time Strategy goes fast paced.Now, when have you heard strategy and intense being used together. At all? It's incredibly rare, and hard to pull off, but Brutal Legends did it. They made a Strategy game that's more than amassing troops and sending them at the enemy base before they reach yours (Although that still works). With nuke solos, powerful double teams, and various other nasty tricks to pull, the RTS element of the game, the Multiplayer Stage Battles, is incredible, capable of turning the tables with the right move, and mixing hack and slash into there so you can join the fun of killing your enemy's troops over and over again! And with three different factions, each with their own playstyle and strategies to pull off, you can enjoy it again and again.If you kile RTS games, Metal, or the works of Double Fine, this is a game that won't disapoint. If you have an aversion to any of these, then run now, and never come back.

 Brutal Legend Brütal Legend is an action-adventure that marries visceral action combat with open-world freedom. Set in a universe somewhere between Lord of the Rings and Spinal Tap, it’s a fresh take on the action/driving genre, which in this case is full of imitation cover bands, demons intent on enslaving humanity and Heavy metal tunes. If you don't already own this game, then you are missing out BIG TIME.Brutal Legend was released on the 26th Feburary 2013 and i am loving this game so far, In this game it has everything a human wants  in a ,Film Music, Entertainment , Comedy, Action and lots more. This game is superb, It is controller supported so i recommend you play with a controller and the driving, the killing is all fantastic.Pros:- Humorous.- Good Driving.- Good actions.- Easy to play.- Liking the single-player.Cons : - The combat is weak.- Freedom of the explorable open world largely wasted.- The action is often floaty.Despite its weaknesses, Brütal Legend pulls it off. It’s the ultimate tribute act, with metal in its soul and a heart as warm as a stage light. It may not have much in the way of polish, especially years after release, but it does have personality – not enough to hide its flaws, but plenty to temporarily bury them under a landslide of rock. I would definitely recommend Brutal Legend and i will give this game a 9/10 because the Weak Combat just didn't impress me that much but this game is FANTASTIC and definitely worth buying.

												That's right, the game hasn't even been released yet and I'm already writing a review for it. What's up with that ? For starters, Brutal Legend is a game that has to be experienced. It's an open world action adventure with a few RTS elements added to it (more on that in a bit). Think of any open world game, add a heavy metal flavour to this world, throw some heavy metal music in there as well and voila, you pretty much have Brutal Legend.It's charming, looks great and above all, it's fun. Except for one thing... Which brings me back to the RTS part. There are a few missions where you have to build an army and engage your enemies in combat, RTS style. And even though it works - it's perfectly playable - it just... It just isn't any fun. It's more of a chore when I think about it. This part is the only negative thing I can think of.But, don't let that keep you from buying it. Brutal Legend, like most of the Double Fine games, is one brilliant game. Do yourself a favor and just buy it already.[Rating: 84/100]

content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												Jack Black all the way; That is the main reason I wanted to play the game, as a big fan of JB and Tenacious D, I must say I am most pleased by his work in this game, filled with puns, spirit and emotions. So many celebrities can be named in the game, Ozzie Osbourne or Kyle Gus are just a few of them, but the list can go on, I highly doubt I will be able to enumerate even half of the good aspects the game has in one quick review.The OST is flawless, with over 100 tracks, the soundtrack is one of the strongest points of the game.The second best point can only be the graphics, which offer divine views, panoramas and ambiances (combined with the soundtrack is just heaven, you could just randomly roam around listening and vieweing for hours), not to mention that the characters are quite well done as well.A good storyline, with lots of twists and teachings, humor and drama, mainly focusing on the rock culture, great concepts, filled with ideas, mainly parodies you could say, of combinations between mytical creatures/objects and rock related elements.The gameplay is quite nice, combining Hack and Slash with RTS in an interesting way, quite unique in my opinion, but it can become difficult on the hardest settings if you haven't mastered the RTS spirit, not to mention against real players.The limitation of the world are one of the negative aspects, it's true you can roam free as much as you want, but you can easily get stuck on hills or branches, because most of the world is stuck itself, not dynamic. Anyways, climbing certain hills or going through certain (original) shortcuts can be impossible and result with you hovering in mid-air without any other way out than restarting from a checkpoint, so in conclusion you do not have freedom of going too sandboxish in the game, due to the many invisible walls.Multiplayer...*sigh*...I can't really say much about it, I am probably not dedicated to it, either not skilled or maybe the matchmaking is faulty, but the few games I played, every time I was finished in a matter of minutes...but I can oversee that, since I played it only for the singleplayer, can't foresee too much fun in a multiplayer game, but in a co-op (if they would have implement such a thing) would have been warmly welcomed.In conclusion, I highly recommend the game because it simply rocks!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Edit: Double Fine, if you ever consider doing Brutal Legend 2, make a Campaign for the Tainted Coil faction, or for that Motorfreaks faction you never finished!Brutal Legend is an Open World Action-Adventure-Hack 'n' Slash-Real Time Strategy Mix, and a pretty damn good one too.You take the role of Eddie Riggs, a Roadie for many super awesome Heavy Metal bands, who ends up being the Roadie for a terrible modern pop tween fake metal band. Because of their carelessness, Eddie ends up dieing on stage. As he dies, his blood awakens the almighty Metal Beast which takes him back in time into the Age Of Metal to fulfill his prophecy of saving humanity from slavery and demons, while teaching them how to harness the power of Metal.All aspects of the game are fairly well done and enjoyable (though this is not the most popular opinion). As you do missions, you unlock more combat moves, guitar solos (summon your car, buff friendlies, etc...), side missions (a good variety of them), vehicle customization (did someone say mounted machine guns?), etc... There's a lot of collectables, hidden secrets, legends, and lore to be discovered. Lots of Metal references and Humor, you'll laugh a lot.The game comes with full controller support as well, and is the recommended device for play.And the best thing about the game, the soundtrack, which you should check out for yourself ;) Have fun!All in all, the best, if not perfect tribute to Rock 'n' Roll and Heavy Metal!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Brütal Legend is not a game - it's an EPIC game. In all caps.The story is hilarious and plays with common cliches. The soundtrack is absolutely superb and so is the voice-acting. The graphics are not state-of-the-art anymore, but this hardly matters since this game is all about chrome and metal anyway. So as long as the bump-mapping is okay: you are cool. Also I truly believe hair-animation was originally invented by some dude that played Brütal and it's only purpose was to allow more realistic head-banging.The game itself hardly sticks with any genre. It takes whatever floats the boat and is the most fun. Meaning it is a road-racing, story-driven, strategic, exploration, adventure, 3rd-person fighting game with RPG elements and Ozzy Osbourne. Also you cast magic spells using an interface that basically looks like Guitar hero.Personally I'm not a big Metal fan. So I may be missing a few puns, but since the focus is on more classic material (even though Metal never gets "classic" it simply becomes more "epic") even an "outsider" like me can enjoy it very much and will recognize many of the characters.The game may be less fun for kids that have not been around in the 19XXies, folks that are dead-serious about their Metal, and people having a favorite activity in bird-watching. (unless it's bird-watching with Metal music)For anybody else: I highly recommend it!

												*Single Player only - I haven't tried multiplayer*Oh Double Fine, how I love you. This game is based around heavy metal, with a wonderful landscape inspired by it and a soundtrack with 20 original compositions and around 80 licensed tracks, and voice actors including Ozzy Osbourne and Jack Black. This game starts off as more of a Hack and Slash, with bits of rhythm and exciting driving sections. Later, a lot more of the game becomes RTS, which on easier difficulties you can win with just brute force over strategy, helpful for those who aren't great at the genre. The teams are also based on metal genres, as well as a wide, interesting variety of different classes for each one, as well as the ability to fight in the fight yourself at anytime. Only real problem with this game is its length, which can be fixed by making a sequel. PLEASE TIM, PLEEEEASE!

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												This game...has flaws.And it still manages to be one of my favourite games of all time,so much that i played about a 100 hours on the original xbox360 version,and pre-ordered it when it came out on pc.You play as Eddie Riggs the worlds greatest roadie,stuck with the lamest "metal" band in existence.After a hilariously awesome beginning cutscene you are brought to a world that seems to be made of album covers.You begin the game slaying your enemies via axe and guitar,but soon you get a car(an awesome hot-rod to be more precise),and later down the line you fight the enemy bosses in a combination action/rts elements.The best part of the game is it's setting.Hands-down it is the most creative world I have ever seen in a sandbox game,and the music(about 90 licensed songs of Heavy Metals greatest,and an excellent original score) just fits it perfectly.The combat is simple but satisfying,and your axe and guitar are customisable.Your hot-rod will also become a fiery machine of death.Missions are varied especially at the beginning,the humor is spot-on,the voice acting is...when you got Jack Black,Rob Halford,Lemmy and Ozzy you know you are doing something right.Now the rts part is where the game suffers a bit.It's hard to really get the hang of it and play beyond just sending out troops randomly,but after a while you'll get used to it.If you like Metal music play this.If you like interesting games play this.Trust me,it is worthy of it's price.Also if possible play with a controller.The pc controls are just fine but still i liked the controller more.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												This game gets two thumbs up, not just one. If you do not wish to read a long, detailed review, know this; Brutal Legend is absolutely brilliant. It has a good story, fast paced gameplay, which combines action and some Real-Time Strategy elements, is semi-open world (more on this later) and has the most rocking soundtrack of any game in living memory. So, what do you get if you purchase Brutal Legend. Firstly, you will find a crisp video introduction featuring Jack Black, introducing you to a record of such rarity, he forgot where it is. When he stumble upon and opens it, you are presented with the best menu system in any game. It is quality, and marks the start of what will become a quality game. After starting the game, you are thrust into the main story. Make no mistake, this game is story driven. It will present you with the illusion of choice, but, really, there is little need to play many of the side quests except to earn Favour of the Gods points, which you can spend on upgrades to your car. The story is suitably epic. I will not spoil anything suffice to say that you are a Roadie for a modern tween-metal band, just getting on with your thing, thinking back to the glory days of metal, when an accident calls you to action. After the carnage has cleared, you awake in a new land, one in which you can harness the power of metal to slay the bad guys. After this, you are tasked with freeing a people, helping with an uprising and vanquishing the oppressors of this world. The characters are excellent, many voiced by prolific figures in rock and metal - Jack Black, Rob Halford, Lita Ford, Ozzy Osbourne, Lemmy, etc. Each character is designed to be the cliche, but this is no bad thing. It adds to the humour of the game.Your character, Eddie Riggs, is armed with a giant axe and a giant axe (this time of the guitar type). With one, you can bash the living daylights out of your opponents, with the other, you can call lightning strikes, small explosions or play solos. The solos are a great game dynamic. Use them to summon your car, raise relics that are used for varying purposes, or simply melt the faces off large groups of enemies. You also use them to capture fans in the RTS parts of the game.This is where the game gets unique. Rather than simply bashing your way through hordes of enemies, you get presented with a battleground at various point in the game. You and your crew build a stage, as does the enemy. This is your base, if you will, and you must protect it. Geysers in the ground spew forth ghostly fans, which you have to capture to boost your fan points. These you can spend to upgrade your stage, your fighters and actually buy your units. The battles are fast paces and frantic, but very enjoyable, at least for a time. Luckilly, this part of the game is not overused. When it is used, it is in the right places, and builds tension. However, for me, there was perhaps one or two too many of these RTS bits. When the rest of the game tries hard to vary what it is doing, these are always a little bit samey, which is a shame. At least the setting changes each time.I completed the game in a single sitting or about 7 hours. I played some of the secondary missions, but not all - I am not a completionist. However, for completionists, you will be happy to know that the main story is only about 50% of the game - there is still plenty to do. For the age of the game, the graphics are amazing. It easily holds up with today's games, mainly due to the art style, which is phenominal. It really is a good looking game.Overall, I was thoroughly impressed. I bought the game a long time ago and never played it, but thought, "hey, I may as well give it a go". Thank goodness I did, as it is now one of my favourite games of all time. It is humourous, with its tounge firmly in its cheek, but hell does it rock. Buy this! Buy this now!!!!!!

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												Overview: Brütal Legend is a quirky third person game that mixes open world, action combat, and strategy into a Heavy Metal themed world.  You play as Eddie Riggs, voiced by and modeled to look like Jack Black, whos mission it is to liberate humanity from oppression.  The best word to describe this game is unique, the mesh of different gameplay styles and the manifestation of Heavy Metal into a video game really sets this game apart.  Pros: The coolest thing about this game is the Heavy Metal theme.  The world is literally Heavy Metal brought to life.  Trees are made of metal, spiders spin metal guitar strings, and giant engine parts strew the land.  The environment is well crafted and looks great.  The game has a good sense of humor and you will find yourself laughing at the characters and the situations that arise.  The story is decent and you can find things to do between story missions.  Cons: The first thing you will notice is that the combat is lacking.  It does not flow smoothly between enemies and the provided combos don't seem to do much.  Even though the Heavy Metal theme is the games best aspect, it is also a draw back.  If you do not like Heavy Metal, this game probably isn't for you.  All the music is metal and the characters embody all that is metal.  The mixing of action combat with strategy might be difficult for people to progress through the game.  The strategy portion is the most difficult aspect of the gameplay and requires more effort and planning.  For people who have experience in one genre but not the other, they will probably have a hard time.  That being said, the action combat is actually really easy.  Even playing on the hardest difficulty, I breezed through most of the game.  Lastly, the game is a little short, with the story lasting about 14 hours unless you are spending a lot time on side missions.  Conclusion: Brütal Legend is a unique experience that will keep you laughing at its quirkiness.  It's not a game for everyone, but if you like Heavy Metal and the idea of a world themed after it, you may enjoy this.  If you're looking for something with non-traditional gameplay and not expecting a masterpiece, give this a try.Score: 8.3 / 10

content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Very underrated game imho.The story is very fun and entertaining in my opinion, even if you are not a Heavy Metal Fan (but it helps being one). I think the writers did a good job of combining a great string of original ideas with classic heavy metal lore. Only downside is that the main story is a bit short for my taste (i must confess, i could not get enough of it), linear and the climax was a bit disappointing. They clearly tried too hard to set the story up for a sequel, which probably will never be developed.The gameplay itself is fun, although a slightly repetitive. You basically have 3 kinds of missions: Hack'n'Slay-style main missions, exciting driving missions and the battlefield missions which were a great new idea, but didn't fulfill their potential despite being fun aswell. The optional side missions lack variety and proper incentive (besides some points to buy power-ups and clothes / car kits your really get nothing from them)... they could have done a better job including side missions into the story, like getting 4-5 minor storylines into the game. As I said, it's very linear. Some people may consider it a weak spot, but i think it's cool that you can choose to simply beat the bejeezus out of everyone with the standard moves or get and use all special moves to maximize your efficiency. I personally found the specials generally useless and there was no tactical aspect to the game... it's more of an arcade-style gameplay. Controls are ok on PC, but you clearly notice this game was made primarily for consoles and "dumbed down" for a broader audience. Too bad they failed at promoting it accordingly.Graphics are appropriate for their time and serve their purpose. Don't expect any fireworks... this game is about fun and originality, not cutting edge technology. The Soundtrack is absolutely fantastic and really helps you immerse into the game world. Voice acting is also tremendous with tons of cool guest appearances (i.e. Kyle Gass of Tenacious D and Lemmy from Motörhead). Level design is absolutely off the hook although you can beat the game by essentially giving your enemies the Diablo 2-barbarian-treatment  all the time (charge head-on - kill everything in sight with brute force - move on). Bottom line: This game is a one-trick-pony, but that one trick is really really awesome. It's not worth a release-date pricetag, but a solid and fun game. If you want about 20-30 hours of straightforward fun and a short, yet entertaining story to fill some "time off" from the games you usually play, you'll have a good time with BL. If you are someone that prefers showing off his/her skills, looting/practicing for multiplayer games or spend hours getting every achievement, i recommend sticking to some MMORPG or FPS.

Posted: May 1, 2014
												This is an awesome tongue in cheek tribute to all that is Heavy Metal. In typical Double-Fine tradition the world is presented in an inventive manner, with a cast of interesting characters, voiced by an excellent line up. Pros- Awesome Metal soundtrack (and official score for that matter)- Good sense of humour- Fantastic selection of voice actors and Heavy Metal cameos - World is fun to explore - Reasonably good pacing (teaching and unlocking most abilities at a good rate)Cons- RTS sections may put you off if you are expecting purely hack-and-slash.- It's not really obvious how much damage you are inflicting or is being done to your units (there are some visual hints, but in the heat of the RTS sections I wasn't really picking up on these)- (RTS) Tanking isn't really an option, so most unit upgrading/advancing feels pointless (even on hardest difficulty)I've had a blast playing this. I'd recommend this for Heavy Metal fans in particular for the soundtrack and whimsical take on the genre(s).  :)

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												OK so when Double Team made this game I was pretty excited. I heard a lot of things before this came out, and I heard even more after it was released. As a metal fan, I had to own this game someday.Unfortunately it was only till a couple of weeks ago that I was first able to play it. I knew this was a game to enjoy because of the cameo's and references, and because I didn't expect any news-breaking gameplay I wasn't in a rush to get it.I must tell you: I was NOT dissapointed.First of all, when you buy this as an appreciator of either old classic rock (Menowar, Judast Priest, Black Sabbath, etc.) or just plain metal (Megadeth, 3 Inches of Blood, Children of Bodom and almost too many more) you will enjoy it. When I saw Ozzy Osbourne almost my whole life flashed by because of his pure awesomeness. And of course Rob Halford as Lionwhite, Lemmy as The Kill Master and more. But even smaller cameo's like Tim Curry (Rocky Horror Show), Metalocalypse-writer and actor Brian Posehn and Jack Black's sidekick Kile Gas.And last but not least; Jack Black... In real life almost such a hero as in Brutal Legend (except saving the earth as a Roady by preforming awesome solo's and creating whole stages and merchandise booths by pure awesomeness). Second comes gameplay. Yes, un purpose. Because if you are more interested in the works of Tim schafer and Double Fine you will find this game probably dissapointing (unless you are actually interested in the 'fun themes' of Double Fine). Yes, the humor does return in this game, even in a large amount! But gameplay wise this is certainly not news-breaking (as my suspicion already indicated). However, even though the game failed to be a good sandbox/rpg game, it did succeed in being unique and diverse. There are a lot of minor quests that are fun, unique and awesome to play when you lost interest in the main quest (which is nothing special, I should mension. Just fun, nothing special..).A last, third thing I should mention is the driving mechanism. I liked this game a lot, mainly because it was good in being mediocore and awesome, but driving in this game is almost impossible. You quickly lose control of your vehicle, it will change direction after the slightest bump in the road, and it can bring you on surfaces you can't walk away from (which makes you restart the game from last checkpoint). I recommend this game, once again, for being an Awesome, Fun and Brutal piece of mediocore game; ups and downs when it comes to gameplay, but the best when it comes to humor and appearances!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												The legendary fire beast, the molten iron monster, and the creamator of the sky. Ormagoden. His steel flesh, burning blood, and an earth shattering roar delivers the player to the promised land of rock.An open world stuffed to brim with Metal. Ground urchins growing iron quills. Steel spiders spinning guitar strings. Boars powered with engines. Mammoths with chromed tusks reflecting the beauty of the Ormagoden's flesh and blood shattered and spilled to create the perfect world.The game is a masterpiece of visual design with every character, monster and landmark placed right where it belongs precisely the way it fits the puzzle. Voices are on point. The story is engaging and will keep you guessing to the very last battle. Heck... Even the main menu itself blows one's mind. Don't get me started on the soundtrack. Ormagoden's mighty roar with a mix of passionate Ethulia's song has blessed the land of rock with the most iconic pieces of metal. The songs included are by themselves worth the price of the game.RTS element of the game is however a bit tricky, fast paced with blitzkrieg being the most if not only reliable strategy. Once you lose some ground there is no climbing back up. Outside of this one the game is amazing and scores a perfect triple six on my awesomeness scale.

Posted: December 4, 2013
												Brütal Legend, the most hilariously awesome game I've played thus far. A game made by metalheads for metalheads like me.The characters, oh god, they are cool, and not because they look cool, it's because they are some of the most respected musicians out there, like Jack Black, Lemmy Kilmister, Ozzy Osbourne, Rob ****ing Halford!. The combat is what I'm used to do on these games, just run around, find an enemy, axe it till it's dead. Yeah, it can be repetitive and boring, but with such a world to explore, you'll have fun uncovering secrets while going on a killing spree with your lovely axe and guitar.And of course, what's a Heavy Metal game without Heavy Metal music? Well, don't panic, this one comes loaded of Metal tracks just to pleasure your ears. The soundtrack goes from KISS, Megadeth, Judas Priest, Slayer and many others. Though I prefer Death Metal, there's little of it on the game. I wish it had a song from Death on the soundtrack, like "Together as One" or "Flesh and the Power it Holds".Overall, this game will keep you entertained during many hours, just enjoying jamming your guitars to shock (literally) your enemies and then fend them off with your trusty Axe. If you are an open-minded metalhead or just someone looking for a bit of fun while slashing enemies, give this a try, you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Very good thematic game for those who worship the Gods of Rock.The mechanics of the game does not invent very much new compared to the GTA series or similar titles, but the theme choice and the environment makes this game really loveable.During the game you fight as Eddie Riggs, a roadie who travelled to a fantasy-world where the Rock and its followers is suffering under the tyranny of the evil Doviculus. As a no suprise you have to fight against it.The main story is not that immersing, but for someone who loves rock music the references to rock bands, songs and other topics (like making business from the art) are outstanding. To highlight the other weak point of the game, it can be repetitive as most of the missions are about fighting alone or a strategy-part where you have to command your units against the enemy. This also true for the secondary missions (3-4 types) and the boss fights (about the same).On the other hand incorporating all the rock-relevant features is amazing. From the music you hear during traveling, the characters, the voice actors (Ozzy is still great), the composure and all the tiny details about them are spectacular. The Double Fine guys and girls really put everything rock-related into the game that deserves discovering. Also the composure of Mr. Crowley with one of the tragic part of the game is an iconic moment.There are many other things that can be mentioned, but as a summary you will value this game if you like the rock music (especially '70s and '80s metal) even if other parts of the game not so original. So Rock On. Brütally.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Brütal Legend is a fun game, but the world and the characters are what make it. The worldbuilding is rich and the often hilarious fusion of metal and fantasy is truly great - stuff like the Screaming Wall, a massive wall of speakers and amps that crackles with feedback-thunder as the microphone-seagulls circle above. The story is well written, the voice acting is excellent, and the animation gives life to characters that in other games would be flat stereotypes or caricatures. Actual gameplay can be a little unwieldly at times, but not overly so, and everything else is so awesome that it didn't bother me too much.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2013/05/brutal-legend.html

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												OK so when Double Team made this game I was pretty excited. I heard a lot of things before this came out, and I heard even more after it was released. As a metal fan, I had to own this game someday.Unfortunately it was only till a couple of weeks ago that I was first able to play it. I knew this was a game to enjoy because of the cameo's and references, and because I didn't expect any news-breaking gameplay I wasn't in a rush to get it.I must tell you: I was NOT dissapointed.First of all, when you buy this as an appreciator of either old classic rock (Menowar, Judast Priest, Black Sabbath, etc.) or just plain metal (Megadeth, 3 Inches of Blood, Children of Bodom and almost too many more) you will enjoy it. When I saw Ozzy Osbourne almost my whole life flashed by because of his pure awesomeness. And of course Rob Halford as Lionwhite, Lemmy as The Kill Master and more. But even smaller cameo's like Tim Curry (Rocky Horror Show), Metalocalypse-writer and actor Brian Posehn and Jack Black's sidekick Kile Gas.And last but not least; Jack Black... In real life almost such a hero as in Brutal Legend (except saving the earth as a Roady by preforming awesome solo's and creating whole stages and merchandise booths by pure awesomeness). Second comes gameplay. Yes, un purpose. Because if you are more interested in the works of Tim schafer and Double Fine you will find this game probably dissapointing (unless you are actually interested in the 'fun themes' of Double Fine). Yes, the humor does return in this game, even in a large amount! But gameplay wise this is certainly not news-breaking (as my suspicion already indicated). However, even though the game failed to be a good sandbox/rpg game, it did succeed in being unique and diverse. There are a lot of minor quests that are fun, unique and awesome to play when you lost interest in the main quest (which is nothing special, I should mension. Just fun, nothing special..).A last, third thing I should mention is the driving mechanism. I liked this game a lot, mainly because it was good in being mediocore and awesome, but driving in this game is almost impossible. You quickly lose control of your vehicle, it will change direction after the slightest bump in the road, and it can bring you on surfaces you can't walk away from (which makes you restart the game from last checkpoint). I recommend this game, once again, for being an Awesome, Fun and Brutal piece of mediocore game; ups and downs when it comes to gameplay, but the best when it comes to humor and appearances!

												I own 3 copies of this game (PS3, X360, PC) and have played them all entirely. While my Steam playtime doesn't reflect complete playthrough, that is because I also received a DRM free copy via Humble Bundle. I can't recommend this game enough! Posted: December 22, 2016
												It's a divisive game. I'm among those who really enjoyed it, but I totally understand those who did not.It's a 3rd person action adventure game with periodic RTS-lite battles. None of the individual elements are particularly special, but they all work together in a way that's more than the sum of their parts. You maintain your full 3rd-person control and moves during the RTS battles, and some of the strategy units will appear throughout the world that you can team up with and lead around to help in fights.The soundtrack is fantastic, with a healthy blend of a wide variety of subgenres and time periods from metal and rock history. I'm a fan of metal so I had an inherent interest, but I've been told by friends who don't listen to metal regularly that the metal jokes were still funny and the soundtrack was enjoyable and thematically appropriate.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												This game gets two thumbs up, not just one. If you do not wish to read a long, detailed review, know this; Brutal Legend is absolutely brilliant. It has a good story, fast paced gameplay, which combines action and some Real-Time Strategy elements, is semi-open world (more on this later) and has the most rocking soundtrack of any game in living memory. So, what do you get if you purchase Brutal Legend. Firstly, you will find a crisp video introduction featuring Jack Black, introducing you to a record of such rarity, he forgot where it is. When he stumble upon and opens it, you are presented with the best menu system in any game. It is quality, and marks the start of what will become a quality game. After starting the game, you are thrust into the main story. Make no mistake, this game is story driven. It will present you with the illusion of choice, but, really, there is little need to play many of the side quests except to earn Favour of the Gods points, which you can spend on upgrades to your car. The story is suitably epic. I will not spoil anything suffice to say that you are a Roadie for a modern tween-metal band, just getting on with your thing, thinking back to the glory days of metal, when an accident calls you to action. After the carnage has cleared, you awake in a new land, one in which you can harness the power of metal to slay the bad guys. After this, you are tasked with freeing a people, helping with an uprising and vanquishing the oppressors of this world. The characters are excellent, many voiced by prolific figures in rock and metal - Jack Black, Rob Halford, Lita Ford, Ozzy Osbourne, Lemmy, etc. Each character is designed to be the cliche, but this is no bad thing. It adds to the humour of the game.Your character, Eddie Riggs, is armed with a giant axe and a giant axe (this time of the guitar type). With one, you can bash the living daylights out of your opponents, with the other, you can call lightning strikes, small explosions or play solos. The solos are a great game dynamic. Use them to summon your car, raise relics that are used for varying purposes, or simply melt the faces off large groups of enemies. You also use them to capture fans in the RTS parts of the game.This is where the game gets unique. Rather than simply bashing your way through hordes of enemies, you get presented with a battleground at various point in the game. You and your crew build a stage, as does the enemy. This is your base, if you will, and you must protect it. Geysers in the ground spew forth ghostly fans, which you have to capture to boost your fan points. These you can spend to upgrade your stage, your fighters and actually buy your units. The battles are fast paces and frantic, but very enjoyable, at least for a time. Luckilly, this part of the game is not overused. When it is used, it is in the right places, and builds tension. However, for me, there was perhaps one or two too many of these RTS bits. When the rest of the game tries hard to vary what it is doing, these are always a little bit samey, which is a shame. At least the setting changes each time.I completed the game in a single sitting or about 7 hours. I played some of the secondary missions, but not all - I am not a completionist. However, for completionists, you will be happy to know that the main story is only about 50% of the game - there is still plenty to do. For the age of the game, the graphics are amazing. It easily holds up with today's games, mainly due to the art style, which is phenominal. It really is a good looking game.Overall, I was thoroughly impressed. I bought the game a long time ago and never played it, but thought, "hey, I may as well give it a go". Thank goodness I did, as it is now one of my favourite games of all time. It is humourous, with its tounge firmly in its cheek, but hell does it rock. Buy this! Buy this now!!!!!!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Brütal Legend is not a game - it's an EPIC game. In all caps.The story is hilarious and plays with common cliches. The soundtrack is absolutely superb and so is the voice-acting. The graphics are not state-of-the-art anymore, but this hardly matters since this game is all about chrome and metal anyway. So as long as the bump-mapping is okay: you are cool. Also I truly believe hair-animation was originally invented by some dude that played Brütal and it's only purpose was to allow more realistic head-banging.The game itself hardly sticks with any genre. It takes whatever floats the boat and is the most fun. Meaning it is a road-racing, story-driven, strategic, exploration, adventure, 3rd-person fighting game with RPG elements and Ozzy Osbourne. Also you cast magic spells using an interface that basically looks like Guitar hero.Personally I'm not a big Metal fan. So I may be missing a few puns, but since the focus is on more classic material (even though Metal never gets "classic" it simply becomes more "epic") even an "outsider" like me can enjoy it very much and will recognize many of the characters.The game may be less fun for kids that have not been around in the 19XXies, folks that are dead-serious about their Metal, and people having a favorite activity in bird-watching. (unless it's bird-watching with Metal music)For anybody else: I highly recommend it!

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												(Four horns for the metal; two for the game itself)This is fantastic game for metal heads, primarily, for all the in-jokes and chuckle-worthy self awareness. Black's dialogue and delivery is priceless as is the fantastic writing by Mr. Schafer himself. The PC version is more than 'just a port', looking and moving far superior to the console editions. The controls are fantastic, specifically with a gamepad. The only issue I have with the game, really, is that combat can be far too simplistic and frantic to be as fun as one might imagine it would be. Also, once the game introduces RTS elements in the form of squads and minions, it goes from 'true metal' to 'nu-metal' in terms enjoyment. That being said, there is a great story here with an enjoyable cast of characters and satirical achetypes. The game overall is great fun, and exploration and a joy. It's a shame that it couldn't decide if it was an adventure game, beat 'em up or a strategy game.

Posted: December 27, 2016
												Brutal Legend is to put it simply, a love letter to metal, its easy to tell. From Jack Black being the main character, to Ozzy Osbourne as the shopkeeper and god of metal. This game uses as many iconic things that makes up metal and its culture. The game has 3 main gameplay mechanics, its a beat em up with heavily used driving mechanics and strategy game mechanics mashed together. If strategy games like Comand and Conqure isn't your thing then don't worry, its not filled with it and its more action oriented than those counterparts. The only main complaint is the game's length, it shouldn't take much time at all if you really wanna try a speed run of it, so if you're looking for a long and joyful distraction, Burtal Legend is FUN and a great time, but it won't be able to go for long especially if you care for only the main story. Other than that this is a great hack and slash, open world game with a huge love for metal, with a soundtrack of artists like Ozzy, Black Sabbath, Motorhead, Megadeth, Diamond Head, and so forth; this game is even better when you're a metal head!8/10 - If longer I would whole heartedly give it a 10/10! Double Fine needs to make a sequel!!!

Posted: November 24, 2016
												I own 3 copies of this game (PS3, X360, PC) and have played them all entirely. While my Steam playtime doesn't reflect complete playthrough, that is because I also received a DRM free copy via Humble Bundle. I can't recommend this game enough! Many were put off by the surprise RTS elements that were introduced after the beginning, but if you stick with the game to explore the most metal world ever created, the best soundtrack hands-down, and the amazing comedic performances and writing from the staff (which includes Tim Schafer, Jack Black, Rob Halford, Lemmy Kilmister, Lita Ford, Ozzy Osbourne), you will not be disappointed.I can't think of a single negative thing to say about this game, except for maybe the marketing. It was a bit deceptive trying to disguise the game as something it was not, but if you have $5 you could probably buy a copy for youself and another copy for a friend. I've done this on multiple occasions, and I advise others to do this as well so people can appreciate one of the best games that sadly went unnoticed by too many.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Brutal Legend is secretly a masterpiece classic game that any gamer should play.  If you are a fan of heavy metal, or of Jack Black, that is bonus.  The game itself has an such a range of unique characters/enemies, visually stunning environments, and excelent game mechanics that it really should be played by every adult gamer.  The game does have very strong language and excessive gore, but that is part of the theme of the story and somehow makes the game better.  The use of the heavy metal theme is done so well.  It's in everything from guitars as your weapons, to mountains of giant speakers to all aspects of the game.  It seems like heavy metal was actually the perfect video game world, or maybe video games are the perfect way to experience the heavy metal world.The game is very affordable, and very entertaining.  I payed $1.50, and have gotten about 20 hours of fun out of the game.  I constantly laugh out loud (literally) at the main character's lines.  I have taken several really awesome screenshots of areas in the game.  I very rarely take a screenshot in a game, so I feel like that is saying something.  Especially when you consider this game is fairly aged.  It still looks amazing in most places.If I were to say anything needed to be changed or added to the game, I would request (As I always do) the ability to play through the campaign in two player coop mode.  The game does have a multiplayer mode, but it is a seperate game type/mode that is really only one of the mini games in the main game.  I would love to go melt faces with a friend!  ...and an HD texture pack.I highly recommend you get this game and play until your face melts.  (or at least until you learn how to perform the face melter in the game)

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												As a gamer, I'm gonna say that I've definetely seen better games than this. As a fan of heavy metal, I'm gonna say it's almost a masterpiece. I got it on sale during the Steam Winter Sales 2016, and I probably wouldn't have bought it for the full price. I thought, wait, is that Jack Black, Lemmy and Ozzy I hear, while watching a trailer, and thought "f**k it, I'm gonna buy it. I'll just write a short resumé that doesn't really spoil anything:ResuméYou start off as a Roadie named Eddie (voiced by Tenacious D lead singer Jack Black), at a gig. A member of the band has climbed up high on the stage, and is now falling down. Eddie manages to save the bandmember, but is crushed by some falling scenery. His blood lands on his belt buckle, in reality an amulet for Ormagöden. The monster Ormagöden then comes to life, and kills the band, and then takes Eddie to a magical world, in which a guitar not only makes sounds, but also blows things up. Eddie wakes up at what looks like a satanic summoning ritual (no surprise, it's a heavy metal game), and will soon have to fight the monsters dressed as monks. He meets a woman named Ophelia (voiced by Jennifer Hale, known for multiple hit video games and TV series, such as WoW, Mass Effect 3, and multiple Star Wars series and games). Together they go and meet a guy named Lars (voiced by Zach Hanks, also vid game voice actor), and together they decide to free the magical world from the tyranny of the evil Lionwhyte (voiced by Rob Halford). Eddie starts off by freeing a bunch the "Headbangers" (get the reference??) from a mine. During the adventures, Eddie meets many different characters voiced by famous heavy metal starts, including:Notable VoiceactorsLemmy Killmister (legendary heavy metal star, founder of Motörhead), voicing the Killmaster.Ozzy Ousbourne (also a legend, from Black Sabbath), voicing The Guardian of Metal.Kyle Gass (deserves to be a legend, from Tenacious D), voicing Kage the Kannonier.Jack Black (just ONE step closer to being a legend than Kage, from Tenacious D), voicing Eddie Riggs.Buy it on sale, unless you are a really hardcore metal fan, then just get it as fast as possible, you're missing out on something golden

												What can I say about this game? Brutal Legend is the very reason why I'm into the music I'm into today; which is of course, Metal! All kinds, but I'm a big fan of Black/Death metal. This game has a heavy emphasis on metal music, with the entire game basically being one big metal album, with a collection of metal songs as well as clever references to other metal bands/songs.One thing that may surprise you is that this is *kind of* an RTS game. About 35%-40% of the way through, you have your first stage battle of the game (of which there are only 5 in single player). The RTS elements were never included in a demo before release because the release of this game got rushed, which is why I think people are a little harsh with this game. People just weren't prepared for RTS :PAbsolutely worth the $15 if you like RTS games, hack 'n' slash games, or if you want to get into metal music! Especially the last one :P9/10

content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												Metalhead's Paradise.The biggest project by Double Fine to date released on consoles with the help of EA and self-published 3 years later on PC, Brütal Legend is the ultimate videogame tribute to metal as a music genre. The game features stars like Jack Black and Ozzy Osbourne, absolutely kick♥♥♥♥♥soundtrack that can satisfy tastes of pretty much any true metal fan old and new (who said "nu"?), shines with great humour and takes place in a rich and creative open world that feels truly alive with real-time day and night cycle and variable weather.Gameplay-wise it starts as an extremely fun slasher but halfway through turns itself into a somewhat hectic action-strategy which may turn many people off, but take your time to master its mechanics and you will find hours of entertainment within, which further extends into the game's multiplayer part.A must-have for every true metalhead regardless of their sub-genre preferences and just a fun open-world slasher / action-strategy game for everyone else.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Brütal Legend is a fun action/adventure game with a lot of comedy in the World of Metal which is now been enslaved by a demon, and you Eddie Riggs, need to free it. The game has a great atmosphere with excellent music and responsive combat system. Also the game manages to mix open world action with some strategic grand scale battles with bosses. Graphics and art design are also Brütal and appealing to look at.Probably the only problem is that the AI sometimes plays it easy, while other times make it really hard for you, mostly on these strategic stage sessions. These battles therefore can be a little stiff sometimes and hard to beat. Issuing orders and keeping the battlefield together is also really hard in this view.The side missions are fun, but after a while you will see that most of them are repeating quests and they are the same except for some.The game is fairly long (around 12 hours) with (a my opinion) kinda lame ending. There is a multiplayer also, but without matchmaking, so you can pretty much just play with your friends.Brütal Legend is a rare gem in the action genre and a very fun game to play. I would definitely recommend to metal/rock fans, or even those who are just looking for some fine action.8/10 Awesome !

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												This is the most Metal game you have ever played, and probably will ever play. If you play it. I'll be honest here, this is a pretty unique game, not just in music and art direction, but also in gameplay. If you hate Metal I doubt you're going to enjoy the game and its story very much, which is filled with nods to those elements. It practically lives of it. So, this review is based on the fact that you ♥♥♥♥ing love Metal.The story is pretty decent, it's got great voice acting, still enjoyable graphics, good cutscenes, interesting characters and villains (at least some of them), though you'll never going to get to dig too deep, so the characters remain somewhat shallow mostly. Still, a fun ride.Bonus points for some rock and metal legends being represented in the game: Lemmy, Ozzy, Jack Black himself of course...From a technical view point, the game still holds up about 7 years later on Windows 10 and works pretty flawlessly. Just make sure to set FOV and camera distance to max. There are some hitches in the vehicles sections, but that's about it. Sound is obviously fantastic.Now let's get on to the gameplay: BEWARE, this game "looks" like a 3rd person brawler, but it's really not. Not at all. While you can and will engage in typical brawls with your weapons, the system is rather basic and you will mostly do so during certain missions and the early stages of the game. Slight spoiler alert: The latter stages of the game (about 2/3s or so) will be more of a RTS, in which you will also fight yourself. This means that you are going to have a base (the stage) and you'll need to capture resource nodes (fans) to train your different units. As the game progresses you get more and more units to choose from. Each of them do something different: There are basic melee and ranged units, a healer, advanced melee and ranged units, siege units, ultimate units, aoe units, etc.These can be ordered around via the D-Pad on your controller to attack, defend, follow, whatever. Many of the later missions revolve around your "tour", i.e. you need to get your tour bus to a certain location at which a stage battle or stage defense will take place. Later on you'll not just have to crush your enemy, but also accomplish certain goals to be able to. You can personally take part in those battles or view them from different angles and just direct your troops, though that won't get you far probably. Better than just hacking away at enemies, however, is the use of your special abilities, called "solos". With these you can buff your allies or "melt the faces" off your enemies for example. Beware that you need to FIND those solos first in the open game world. Without face melter for example the game becomes much more difficult. Same as with solos you can also get upgrades for your character and his car, but you need points for that. You can do side missions to get more of those, but they are not really necessary and they are kinda boring.The stage battles can get a bit tedious after a while, especially if you would rather brawl around, but well, that's just the way the game was designed. If you're really not into that, better not buy and watch a bit on YouTube first or watch the whole story and gameplay.I didn't play the MP portion of the game, but I imagine it's a) pretty much dead and b) probably more stage battles. Since there are 4 factions in the game, each with different units (2 are pretty similar), I assume you can just play as any one of them.Bottom line: If you like Metal, give it a try, on easy it's not too difficult, only the last 2 battles are a bit annoying.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Я натрапив на цю забавку коли читав в Вікіпедії про Містера Кроулі. Скажу прямо, я слухаю надзвичайно багато металу. Я виріс на піснях Озі Озборна, Моторхед, Мегадес та Металіки. Я був здивований коли побачив гру повністю про метал, рок-н-рол та треш метал. Що здивувало мене найбільше це каст гри. Легенди року як Озі, Роб Хальфорд та Леммі Кілмайстер озвучили своїх же персонажів в цій грі мене заставило трішко просльозитися. Також здивували зірки як Джек Блек які вирішили озвучити цю гру. В русифікаторі атмосфера трішки пропадає але люди які вільно говорять англійською мовою можуть насолодитися озвучкою гри.ГеймплейГра це свого роду РПГ від третього лиця. Ви мусите проходити побічні завдання щоб отримати "Fire Tribute", свого роду валюту на яку можна купити апгрейди для своєї сокири, гітари, машини чи нові комбо атаки. Все це можна зробити в спеціальних гаражах, де Озі продає все це добро. Гра такоє має свого роду стратегічну систему. Вона не складна, але цікава. (Навколо неї побудований мультіплейер). Гравець повинен знащити ворожу сцену за допомогою своєї армії. Цей процес можна прирівняти до катки в Доту, але в Brutal Legend гравець не дуе помагає "кріпам". КонтрольСкажу прямо, але я просто ненавидів керувати деусом. Керування мені здавалось важким. та погано зробленим. Особливо ненавидів місію втечі з замку Ліонвайта. Самим персонаем керувати не складно (крім гри соло на гітарі, але до них я швидко звик)СюжетМи грайемо за Едді Рігса (Джек Блек). Еді- роуді який працює на сучасну рок груву "Cabbage Boy." Але Еді ненавить сучасний рок. Він думає що сучасний метал повільно падає на коліна. Одного разу дурний гітарист виліз на статую Еді побудував для концерту. Еді всіх рятує та помирає. Трішки його крові попадає йому в пржку паска що переность його в дивний світ. В новому світі людство забуло що таке метал, через загарбників які відібрали нашу культуру і землю. Еді вступає в ряди супротиву щоби повернути метал та нашу культуру. На своєму шляху Еді зустрічає Майстра Вбивств (Леммі Кілмайстер), Вогняного Барона (Роб Халфорд) та інших персонажів з якими він повинен повернути волю та метал своєму народу.ПідсумкиЯ закохався в цю гру з першого погляду. Мені сподобалося все! Голоса, метал, пасхалки, квести, сюжет та персонажі. Все було мультяшним, кольоровим, дзвінким, але на жаль контролі  трішки портять досвід гри. 												For a game released in 2009, this is great. I had no real knowledge of the game going into it, so I was very suprised when it went from open world to an inovative RTS + third person mixup partway through. A fresh take on the RTS genre coupled with a solid overworld to explore makes for some varied and engaging gameplay. Add on top of that some solid humor brought to you by Jack Black and some other comedic voice actors engaged in a decent storyline and you have yourself a pretty solid experience. It's even got multiplayer which actually might be the biggest aspefct of the game.The main negatives are the somewhat wonky vehicle controls and pretty mundane sidequests. If it were just an open world game it'd be hard to recommend, but there's so much more to it than that.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Really, really great concept and a good story. This game is funny. And I like heavy metal quite much. Therefore, I really wanted to like this game.BUT the controls are untolerable, especially with the car. It's not just me. Every negative review on the Store page mentions the same problem: controls.I also find the camera distance and rotation problematic while driving the vehicles. Also, the game badly communicates the objectives or the means to achieve them. Only if you are doing something wrong for a while, a hint appears. Why not mention what and how to do something in the beginning? Why I have to keep guessing? Sometimes, I achieve victory right away, sometimes I need to try few more times. Either way I don't know what I did right or wrong. Things just happen in this game. The game has no mini-map, therefore I need to check the global map all the time. The game has no healthbar, therefore I don't know, how much health I've left. What's even worse: the game poorly communicates, whether you've received damage or gave damage. Also, it's hard to distinguish between friendly units and enemy units. For every friendly unit you have a matching enemy unit, who looks almost the same. The minor differences are noticeable only from a close distance. Also, the heavy emphasis on guitar solos doesn't make things any more convenient (you need to press a certain button combination during the solos and you are vulnerable to attacks for a few seconds before the solo is through).Real-time strategy, racing, adventure, hack-n-slash - this game has mixed so many elements, but none of them is done properly. The game has a good soundtrack and story and that's about it. Everything else is just chaos happening between the cutscenes. Therefore, I cannot recommend this game. The gameplay is torment.But I do recommend to watch the cutscenes on YouTube. If you perceive Brutal Legend as a cartoon, it's great, especially, if you know a bit about the history of metal and hard rock music.My overall rating: 6/10

												Provided that you like (or at least tolerate) all of the following:  Various forms of Metal music and all the imagery that comes with them, 3D Beat-em-ups, Driving, Exploration, RTS games, chatty NPCs, and the voices of Jack Black, Tim Curry, and Ozzie Osbourne... this may very well be your new favorite game EVER.  It's charming and imaginative, funny, and utterly awesome.But if any one of those elements would be an absolute deal-breaker for you, well... you can't really avoid any one of them altogether, although I did manage to fudge through most of the campaign's RTS segments with a one-man-army approach; the car becomes really OP in single-player.Oh yeah, there's also a competitive mode, in which you can play as the factions that were strictly enemy opponents in the single-player campaign, but you REALLY have to be into the RTS mechanics to stand a chance there.

												So I really, really enjoyed this game!Yes, me, the guy who normally thinks gameplay is the absolute most important element in any game, thinks Brutal Legend is a great game!The gameplay is... not rubbish, but really nothing special. The actual combat is kinda-fun but still mostly brainless button-mashing. while the pseudo-RTS elements actually IS garbage and not an RTS at all. Driving is still pretty fun though, in a Halo/Borderlands kind of "Not really much benefit to it but still dang fun".But it's everything else that really makes this game what it is! The music is bloody brilliant, the graphics and concept are close to "Lord Of The Rings, as written by stereotypical heavy metal fans" (aka: bloody awesome), and the voice acting and story is... good enough, I guess, I could never really judge voice acting.Basically, did you ever watch Army Of Darkness? Neither did I, I've only seen the trailer. But imagine what that movie would be like if it was just like the trailer, then make it 12 hours long, and you'll know whether you like this game or not.

I would have preferred them going with some old videogame trope like "No, I am the actual big bad guy behind it all, and now you have to fight me" then you turn into Ormagodden (the god in that world) and fight.  I would have been all for that.  This ending just kind of tainted the game for me.  - Its an open world game, and it suffers from open world game tropes like repetive missions, fetch quests, and hunting for collectibles- Repetitive voice-overs, "We're just marching around kicking♥♥♥♥♥quot;- Like I said, the first 30 minutes are awesome, the rest of the game, the humor and pacing kind of fall flat.  I really feel like they could have done so much more with what they had here.  - Some of the characters are under developed.- The vehicle controls are very brick-ish.  That being your primary mode of transportation for the entire game makes brick-ish handling unacceptable.  - The pop-in.  I know this is a console port, but even with the draw distance maxed out, I still had things materializing right in front of me.  Its just kind of annoying.  So, with all this said, I am still recommending this game... only if you are a fan of the music genre.  Otherwise, stay away.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												One of the biggest points of this game is Heavy Metal and its imagery: Long-haired head bangers (with comically -unless you are a F1 pilot- sized necks), cool and sexy (In the eighties sense of sexy) biker girls, huge metal-themed statues bursting out of the ground, giganitc anvils with lava rives flowing, riffs, demons, epic battles, motorcycles speeding, and beer and horns everywhere. Is one of those games made by someone who enjoyed the medium it references and which grow in it. This is not a "let's push some random generic references to heavy metal" (as so many games have done before with the eighties), but a truly unique and well crafted journey through the perspective of actual metal fans of what the "Land of Metal" is.Thus, if you know who Rob Halford is, or if you use (or used) to headbang with Ronnie James Dio, you will feel here at home, laugh with (almost) every joke and smile at every single reference, and really enjoy how the world of metal and some of its sub genres is represented, all glued together with one of the best licensed OST's lawyers and money can put together. You got no idea about classic heavy metal? Then lookup "Brütal Legend Soundtrack playlist" and choose the playlist with MORE THAN 100 LICENSED SONGS. Titanic effort to please your ears while riding through the land of metal.The mandatory horns are here -> \m/, so we can keep going.This is a classic Double fine game in what background and history refeers: Its ♥♥♥♥ing great. At every single level. Characters are funny and well developed (Voiced in the original version by people like Jack Black or Lemmy Kilmister), the artistic side of the game is impressive at almost every single level, with different zones of the map following different substyles of heavy music, huge creatures which seems to have just escaped from a Judas Priest cover roaming the land... visually everything is in its place and ready to rock, achieving a weird mixture between some of the best designs for both creatures and landscape I've seen, alsoo imbued with a classic spirit straight from the beginning of the eighties. Also, the (epic) history, filled with demons, vikings, gods of metal and a "as subtle as an atom bomb" reference to Motörhead would fit without problem in a conceptual album from Manowar or Dio. The main problem with the game is that it tries to cover way too much features. You got a car which you can use to roam the Land of Metal listening to the different heavy metal songs mentioned earlier. You can fight with axe and guitar (yeah and guitar, HELL YEAH!) against multiple enemies. And you can direct battles in a simple-RTS style, in which it seems to be the main focus of the game. Everything can be upgraded, everything has combos, but almost nothing is deeply explored.You never got to a smart designed melee fight past the first level, nor you get more activities than racing with your car, and the RTS battles aren't exactly food for fans of the genre, as most of them are really simple "go ahead with everyone until you destroy the enemy base" missions, something that, on the other hand, is to be grateful for as the RTS controls (designed to use a console pad) are improvable, if I had to be polite. The crappy thing about all of this is that I'm not complaining about the game being bad (besides the poor RTS controls), but because I WANT MORE AND BETTER. The hack and slash deserves levels playing together with Ofelia (The female companion of the main character), the open world deserves to be bigger and more detailed, the RTS deserves to have proper mouse + keyboard controls so I can actually think on performing more complex strategies, like banding together with some infantry and attack in a mosh pit while a squad of bikers from hell cover our asses.I liked the game. A lot. I enjoyed every reference, listened to every song (Even discovered some groups that have gone under my radar), laughed at every joke and enjoyed a ride in a world I want to go back to. But I have serious doubts as if someone who wouldn't enjoy the background of the game would enjoy the gameplay itself, with its cool things, but also with its many flaws.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2013
												One of the most artistically creative games I have seen hit from the 7th console generation. Everything in the game is a celebration of all things rock and metal, and as such, it has a ton of great music in it and personality and charm oozes out of this game's pores. I was really pleasantly surprise when Double Fine put in the effort themselves to get this originally PS3/360-exclusive and EA-published game onto the PC, and then even Mac and Linux, when they originally had no plan to do so, much like how they went back and gave Psychonauts a new shine on PC/Mac. It's a good port of a good, straightforward game, and I don't think it sold very well during its initial release, so major kudos to Double Fine for believing in their game and expanding it to reach new audiences. I thoroughly enjoyed this open-world hack-n-slashy journey, including those somewhat strange RTS-like parts you may have heard about. A truly inspired and fun, unforgettable game with a lot of heart and a brilliant vision.

This is a game, ladies and gentlemen, that properly represents the spirit of Metal. Should you thirst for blood and lightning, for power and amazement, for a five-star cast and white-knuckle writing, then spend your money on this fantastic game.  Play it, enjoy it, and cherish it.  It's well worth your time.

												It's hard to review this game as it has many great ideas, but also many horrible ones. And sometimes even those great ideas are horribly executed. The game is a hybrid 3rd person action adventure with RTS elements with racing elements. Truth be told, I spent 3/4 of the game in Deuce, the beefed up car, mostly because the 3rd person combat and RTS elements are rather poorly executed. The game's story is quite an interesting one and cameos from many well known metal figures are rather funny and/or interesting. All in all if you like metal music, just buy the game. You will enjoy many many things while enduring the cumbersome parts. \m/ If you don't like metal music, or if you're just indifferent to it, there is nothing for you here. Nearly every aspect of the game lacks polish and it's not worth going through all the shortcomings to enjoy the nice story.
