												*INITIAL IMPRESSIONS*Inside my dusty, cobweb infested mind there were two debating sides of my shattered phsyce, one of them saying not to jump a sh*t and buy Brutal Legend just because of it's TF2 promotional item, and the other side saying "naw scruu u". Guess which side won.Initially, I'm somewhat glad that side was victorious. Brutal Legend is from what I've seen so far (little over half and hour) a third person hack-n-slash adventure game. The controls are simple and easy to pick up on but at the same time leave room to enhance one's skill with combos and strategy.  Graphics wise it leaves a tad to be admired, and the game has a fussy camera system which is especially prominent in the vehicle segments. I don't have any right to make a comment on the story yet, but I can say that the writing has a charming, casual approach to the brutal nature of the games world. The game also features Jack Black (School of Rock, Kung-Fu Panda) as Eddie Riggs, while I'm not the biggest fan of Jack Black I honestly can't see anyone else filling in the role except for him.So far, it's a pretty fun experience, it's rather obvious that it's been ported from the Playstation but that hardly gets in the way of the gameplay. FYI, these are my initial thoughts on the game, further into the game they may change.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												What if Dorothy was super into heavy metal and Oz thus reflected that? That's basically what happens with Brutal Legends. You get sucked into a world full of trees made of car mufflers, spiders that spin steel bass strings instead of web, and a "Wailing Wall" made up of giant guitar amps instead of bricks and mortar.The story is incredibly tongue-in-cheek and had me chuckling on several occasions. They poke fun of heavy metal throughout the game, but at the same time you can tell they have a deep love for it. It has great voice acting (Jack Black normally gets on my nerves but he's fine here), and an excellent soundtrack (assuming you can tolerate heavy metal).The gameplay is your standard open-world character action game, but what sets it apart is the RTS element which is pretty divisive. Personally, I love it, and am surprised more people didn't get into it. They've spun it out into a full-fledged multiplayer mode with matchmaking, and I'm looking forward to digging into it even more. It does have a steep learning curve, but once you get the basics down there is a lot of fun to be had.Definitely a game worth checking out if you haven't already.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												TLDR – Brutal Legend is a third person hack / slash game with some simple rhythm elements and a sprawling single player campaign. There’s a lot of humor to be found, probably due to the lead character being played by comedian Jack Black. It’s also got a lot of foul language, so be warned if that kind of thing offends your sensibilities (you get the option to add censors).In the story, you play Eddie Riggs, a heavy metal music “roadie” whose job it is to follow rock stars around fixing things and setting everything up to make the band look awesome while staying out of the spotlight himself. Through a mystical event, you are cast into the distant past (The Age of Metal) ruled by a demon named Doviculus, and inhabited mostly by monstrous creatures. The whole game has a heavy metal music theme, including rock concert battles, playing music to cast spells (kind of like songs in Ocarina of Time), and a lot of cameo appearances by famous rock musicians. Most of the gameplay is straightforward third person hack slash where you use your trusty axe and just swing until the enemy is dead (you can buy more special attacks later on). You also have a magic guitar to play songs for special effects, and as the story progresses you learn more and more songs to play. You also spend a lot of time driving around the open world in a car that you can summon (one of the first songs you learn). Like with most open world games, this means that the map is filled with optional missions and racing minigames, as well as artifacts that you can find for “fire tributes.” Fire tributes are the “money” of the game, and despite the game playing like an RPG, you don’t level up or get experience when fighting. You acquire the fire tributes and spend them on power ups and cosmetics for your character. One note that I’ll make is that a lot of the purchasable items are unlocked as the main story progresses, so don’t bother doing all the missions and hunting down collectibles too early in the game, since you won’t be able to buy much anyways until later on.Pros:+Despite not having the greatest graphics, it is clear that the game developers spent a lot of time on the scenery and overall game world. The main characters may look cartoony, but the otherworldly environment is great. If you’ve played Just Cause 2, you should know what that’s like (gameplay graphics better than cutscene graphics). If you enjoy rock music, you’ll be in for a treat as well. Driving along with the soundtrack is pretty fun.+The game’s story is engaging and well written. Since the game world is so different from our own, the writers were free to come up with some interesting villains and history. Maybe you don’t like Jack Black’s style of comedy, but I thought it worked well with this particular game. He’s probably better known for childish humor/movies, but Brutal Legend has some mature themes.Cons:-As with many games of this type (open-world) there are a huge number of collectibles to be found and if you’re like me you probably don’t want to go out of your way searching for them after the game’s story is over. It turns out that you won’t have enough money to buy all the upgrades unless you hunt down most of the collectibles. There’s no easy way to do it either, even with an online guide because the game’s world map is kind of weak.-One weird thing I noticed is that the game never actually tells you how to unlock some of these collectibles (using fire spells or thunder clap skills). I had to look it up online. This is a minor gripe though, since most collectibles just give you some fire tributes to spend. I was able to beat the game my first playthrough without buying much. The majority of purchasable items are cosmetic.Overall, if you liked action adventure games such as Darksiders, but thought they would be better with more humor and less hardcore fighting, you may enjoy Brutal Legend. The game doesn’t take itself seriously, and the silly ways that rock music is woven into the story/gameplay will likely bring an occasional smile to your face.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Some games are made so that you can mindlessly mow down hordes of generic whatsits with your fat, noisy bullet-hose.This is not one of them.Some games are made so that you press A repeatedly in a series of menus so that you can watch your numbers go up every now and then.This is not one of them.Some games are really boring.This is not one of them.This game is an inspirational, madcap epic - in the proper sense of the word.  A single individual against vast and innumerable odds, conquering his way through adversity with nothing short of awe-inspiring trenchancy.  Weild thunder and lightning?  Check.  Throw fireworks?  Check.  Use a guitar as a magical death-array?  Bam, done.  Slaughter enemies with a souped-up motor-car forged by The Ozz of Metal?  Go ♥♥♥♥ing crazy.This is a game that you do not soon forget.  This is a game where they've taken a masterpiece setting and given it a thick, heavy pulse, full of grit and power.  This is a game, ladies and gentlemen, that properly represents the spirit of Metal. Should you thirst for blood and lightning, for power and amazement, for a five-star cast and white-knuckle writing, then spend your money on this fantastic game.  Play it, enjoy it, and cherish it.  It's well worth your time.

Posted: March 15, 2014
												I feel sad for not liking this game. It is a double fine title, and they normally make very interesting games with great designs and a good setting. This also has a very good visual design, and it have taught me that I really like metal, when it does not include growling, because it sounds like a hungover bear, who occasionally beats his wife. So it haves a great soundtrack with a great design for every creature and the whole world. It also wants to do a lot of things, because it combines open world, hack and slash, racing and real time strategy, and it really destroys every aspect of it. The hack and slash is the best part of it. It only needs two buttons on the mouse to fight and there are some combos and such. It does however just become repetetive and easy, since there are not really any major penalty for death. Then there is the RTS which is just take all your soldiers and destroy things you hate. You just wins anyway, because you chop them up with your axe or drive them over with your car, which brings me to the racing and driving. That is seriously the worst, since your car controls like an♥♥♥♥♥ Good luck with making a turn without ♥♥♥♥ing up. And there are missions where you have to shoot things while driving, and you cannot hit it. The open world is not that great either. It just feels like a very annoying break between missions. Sure there are collectibles and side missions, but they should just let that obtainable through menus. Worst of all, there is no ♥♥♥♥ing minimap. Every open world game needs that, because you do not want to look at your map every minute, when you are lost. The game haves a very metal design, and it is great. Combined with the good humour and Jack Black's cheery voice it do have some good moments, but the whole game is really bad. If you want a great double fine product, then buy Psychonauts, which is cheaper and have a better design. I can only recommend this to hardcore Jack Black or metal fans.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Pros:— Awesome universe, beautifully crafted and immersive— Pretty good graphics— Killer soundtrack— Great scenario, with depth and twists— Delicious cameos from Lemmy, Ozzy, etc.Cons:— Frustrating controls (no jumping, no strafing, and worse: not enough responsivity...)— Too much dialogue, and it doesn't work good (the same NPC sometimes repeats the same line 10 times in 30 seconds)— Too much (useless) cutscenes, especially in the beginning— The RTS part is tedious as balls. And I say tedious, not difficult, because it's just not fun.— Way too often the game threw me into the domain of I DON'T KNOW WHAT THE HELL IS GOING ON AND I HAVE NO IDEA WHAT I'M DOING. That is not a good thing.— Most objectives are absolutely unclear and the trial and error to figure out what the games wants you to do is a hassle.— The fact that there is nothing on the screen (no health meter, no map... nothing) may be "arty" but it doesn't help and makes the game even more confusing.Conclusion: What would have made an absolutely awesome movie makes a game that is okay at best. The fact that the gameplay is a blend of various genres is nice, but not well done. The artistic part is AMAZING, but the gameplay is just not good.5/10.

												First you’ve got to understand that this game is a pool of bugs and glitches, nothing game breaking but when they pile up, all that stick to your memory is a terrible experience.First with the technical bugs, I got the sound not working for me until I figured out what’s the problem, the controller was a mess, when you press a button it input another button for some reason, I wasted hours trying to figure out what’s the problem, I even contacted the support twice but they didn’t respond, I had to learn the hard way that the controller would only work if you’re in the big picture mode in steam, I really don’t understand why but that is exactly what happened.Second is in game bugs, the game keep stuttering even though my pc could easily handle it on maximum settings, and for some weird reason every time you view a landmark the whole UI glitches and you have to restart the game.As for the game itself it has a lot of pros and but more cons, the concept is one of a kind, a metal heaven with some real time strategy, hack and slash and fun, Jack Black is freaking awesome here, as well as all of the other characters, top notch voice acting, great music, beautiful world (slightly small for my taste), badass humor, driving and upgrading a badass car, fly around and admiring the color patterns, I also like the way they ask you at the beginning of the game if you want gore and profanity, it’s so seamless I wish some games would offer similar things, I credit this game for that.The cons are major, for example the game is a mess, you wouldn’t really tell where are your enemies and where is your army, they all look the same from above, no way to tell what’s your current health and what not, too many insufficient mechanics that confused me so much, I don’t think I have the attention span to learn everything, the game is not deserving, it’s not long and rich enough to be worth it in my opinion, this game is just a pack of mess.All in all I don’t recommend this game, the first impression was awesome, but after 7 hours of playing it left a sour taste in my mouth, I really can’t stand playing this game even though I wish I really got into because I loved the idea so much, I just couldn’t even finish this game, I give this game a terrible 3 out of 10.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
Brütal Legend wants to be an ode to metal while being a fun game to play. At times it feels like the world collide good enough to be enjoyable, but as a game it doesn't work as well as it should.The Good:· Introduces gamers to metal and vice versa. If you're a fan of both, you will love this for sure.· Great voice acting, including Jack Black among others.· Creative environmental design...The Bad:· ... but the world itself feels flat and empty. Everything metal-esque is squeezed together in a little enivorment or area, but everything around that feels like a flat world with some stones here and there. It's an open world that doesn't need to be there, but one that exists simply to boost the scale and to keep you busy while going from A to B.· Even though it's sweet to melt the faces of headbangers, the combat feels dull, repetetive and generally useless. There are basic axe-swinging attacks, then there's thunder and lightning to damage your enemies from a small distance. Besides that and some special guiter solo's, that's it. · The enemies have no health bar and neither do you. It feels like you're just mashing buttons to see which one of you drops dead first. Your screen will start flashing if you're nearing death, but by that time it's either too late for you to flee away and keep some distance for a few seconds to do it over again. Some people say the combat is difficult, but I say there isn't enough information given on your screen to know just what you're doing.· The story, albeit filled with iconic characters from the metal world, is dull and uninterresting. The familiar faces are the only reasons to sit through it until the very end.The Ugly:· The game isn't very pretty, but good enough to do the job. Nothing too dated, nothing too superb, just okay. The character models and filled environments are a clever mix between fantasy and rock that helps to make Brütal Legend a little bit more interresting.Final verdict:If you're a metal fan and ejoy the occasional video game, definately get this. If you're the other way around, like myself, then don't. It's 75% metal and 25% game, and Double Fine should have taken another direction with Brütal Legend. It's bigger than it needs to be, but not figuratively big enough to fit in all the potential.5/10

												Tim Schfer the Mastermind behind the cult hit classic Psychonaut did it again with another Double Fine Masterpiece. Brutal Legend.This game has nearly everything a Heavy Metal follower would enjoy. It has Metal. It has rock star cameos everywhere, it has action, drama, Real Time Strategy, Music, comedy and such a compelling storyline that you would go deeper and deeper to learn everything about the world of Brutal Legend.Why should you NOT get this Amazing work of Art? To put it straight you would be amazed by such detail and art that was put into this game to cater to a wide range of Rock enthusists.  To date this game has one of the most Licensed Metal/Rock Songs to date in this EA title. Sure EA as a company is pretty bad but Double Fine has talent that is not to be overlooked.Buy at full price and you will not be regretting it. Buy it at sales and you would be getting a treat for how massive it is!If you enjoy Real Time Strategy, then Stage battles are definately quite an attracting part of it.One gripe I do have though......How come only in the Stage Battles that you are only able to fly while on the Map you cannot? I guess it has to do with glitches/exploits I suppose. Nevertheless. Very graphic Heavy and intense you best have a PC strong enough with enough of processing power to run it.Best First purchase on Steam that I never regretted. Thank you DoubleFine for such an amazing title!

content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												Brütal Legend is a game that tries to combine hack-and-slash with real time strategy. The end result is a cluster♥♥♥♥ that lacks both the mindless brütality of butchering your way through hordes of enemies, as well as any real strategic depth. I ♥♥♥♥ing love metal, and the game's aesthetics and humor, character design, soundtrack - it's amazing. Everything about this game is amazing, except the gameplay. I really enjoyed the start of the game, where it plays solely like a hack-and-slash. Cranked up the difficulty to max and comboed my way through hordes of enemies, and fun bosses. But then the game shoves its weird psuedo-strategy thing in your face, and from that point on most of the game consists almost solely of these so-called "stage battles".The strategy ultimately boils down to rushing down your opponent all day every day, with one huge blob of units. Even if there was room for more elaborate strategies than "send all the dudes forwards", your overview of the battlefield, combined with the hectic hack-and-slash pace of it all makes it impossible to stop and focus for any given moment. You'll find yourself in a situation, then, where you're just trying to charge at enemies and at least enjoy the hack-and-slash - only to realize that everything the game has taught you so far about combos, timing your blocks, and so on, is ultimately pointless. Your only way to make any sizeable difference in a fight is to use "Double Team" - ie. taking control of one or several of your units and spamming their one or two attacks. At least solos are still fun.Bottom line, this game, on paper, might just be the best video game ever made. Though in practice it turns out that hack-and-slash and real time strategy simply do not blend. If we ever get a Brütal Legend which focuses solely on one type of gameplay at a time - preferrably the hack-and-slash - then I might just give the team my entire wallet and call it a day. Until then, might wanna dodge this one.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Update:Thumbs down.After a dozen hours of play, technical issues and repetitive mini-games have killed my interest. I want to love this game for the theme and the aesthetic, but it just doesn't play well. The biggest problem was controller lag - there's a small but serious delay between the time that I push a button, and the time that the game responds. I've found posts from several people who also suffered from controller lag, tried their solutions, but nothing worked for me. This takes most of the fun out of the action sequences. Unfortunately, even if I'd found a solution to the lag, I think the repetitive mini-quests were just too much. How many times can I enjoy beating up the same cloned goon squad? Several. More than one.But not nearly so many times as the game seems to require.Original review:Thumbs up.If you like Jack Black or Tenacious D, then you'll like this game. If not, then you probably won't. As a fan of Tenacious D,  the style and theme of this game totally do it for me. Ever wanted to see what Rodin would do if he'd been a rocker? Then take a short hike to the guitar mountain overlook, where you can admire a gigantic slab of rock, sculpted by the Titans into the shape of pair of hands holding a guitar. Unfortunately, the gameplay is medicre, seemingly unfinished, with many of the missions being awkward or unclear. For example, there are several side-missions involving base-defense. The key to success is getting out in front of tne enemy. Unfortunately, despite cries of "the enemy is coming!" and "they're behind you!" the attacking forces are often hidden by the landscape until just before they reach your base, which means it's hard to see them in time. If there'd just been a HUD arrow, something to point out the direction of new attackers, these missions would have been far more fun.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2013
												Welcome to the Age of Metal, a time before Modern Man.When you first play the game, you might think it's a simple Action-Adventure game, continue playing and you'll find out it's actually a Open-World Action-Adventure game with vehicles and Real Time Strategy.A non-conventional mixing of gameplay, but Double Fine managed to pull it off surprisingly well.The game world is based around it's own Heavy Metal inspired mythology, with a full backstory, and the world filled with such things as trees with mufflers acting as branches, volcanoes with liquid metal as lava, and metal spiders that spin bass strings.The main missions in the game advance the story and has you fighting three factions in your quest to free Man, the missions involve you doing a array of tasks to increase your own faction and unlock new units, along  with doing RTS battles. The game also includes side missions, involving simply defeating a herd of enemies, using your car as a mounted gun, or even racing.On foot the game is pretty standard, with you having two weapons: a Axe for melee attacks and a Guitar that you can do more range attacks like setting enemies on fire and lighting, along with combining them for some combo moves. You can also use your car to go around places, which also contains two weapons, though they can be swapped for more varied types. The rts portion of the game involves you commanding units on foot and in the air (as your character gets the ability to fly with wings), and capture Fans (which show up as vents you have to build Merch Booths on) which you use to get more units and ultimate destroy your enemy's stage.There is also a bunch of stuff to find across the world, giving you more Fire Tributes (used to buy upgrades for yourself and your car), backstory ,or new abilities in the form of playable songs.The game also feels quite short and cut back though, the ending comes rather fast, as a bunch of content was cut including a fourth faction.Overall the game is worth playing, even if you aren't a big fan of metal.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Short version: Good writing, bad controls, and buggy. Get for a console, or avoid entirely.Long version: Brutal Legend is a well written game with a clever spin on the usual hero's journey story arc, with a self-aware sense of humor that makes even some of the failures funny. And that's the good news.Bad news is that the gameplay itself is quite bad. First, you'd best have a controller, because Keyboard/mouse is basically impossible (Even the tutorial is for controller). Moving and attacking are sluggish, you fight the camera more than most enemies, trying to drive is a joke (and don't even think about racing), and the graphics will chuck often, even on a high-end PC.And here's the real kicker. It's unplayable on high-end PCs. There's a bug that crashes when the game clashes with many graphics cards, most of them fairly good. The fix seems to be to UNDERclock your card/system. Yeah, no. I shouldn't need to make my PC worse to play a game. And at this point, there's pretty much no chance of a bug fix for it.With the bug aside, it's a mediocre game that deserved better than what it got. 6.5/10 for the writing and style, but major points lost for the gameplay itself. And then the bugs just add to it. Get it for a console if you really still want this game. The PC version is just another lazy port.

It has a fun story, characters and setting and if you can  get it cheap (I picked it up in a humble bundle) it's probably worth a play through. The problem is it's also a bit crap. It tries to be an epic hack and slash adventure, a driving game, an rts, and a teeny bit of rhythm game thrown in for good measure... and in the end it means that it does none of these things particularly well. The UI occasionally breaks and basic touches that would have made certain things so much more livable and which are present in their other games... just weren't there. If you just want to play through, it's a shortish varied game working on the basis that stuff is awesome and you should come along for the ride. If you're looking for something more in depth, there are better options out there.

												I try to only write reviews for games I've finished but I can't really bring myself to finish or really play much more of Jack Black the game.  For me the game suffers from not really knowing what it wants, its not going to be a hack and slash, or a sandbox/ exploraton game and its not really a good enough RTS to try to claim to be that either.  All the pieces were in place but they didnt really end up fitting together like they needed to which is a shame.  Story wise I quite enjoyed what I saw, I got a few smirks out of the humor and it wasn't taking itself seriously enough to not make fun of how dumb it was, which really worked for it.  The soundtrack is worth mentioning as it is amazing, truly wonderful in my opinion:  all the clasic metal you could want or tolerate at all the right times.  The art style too is not bad, the disproportionate characters and the metal world all look really nice and are fun to see and explore.  But it all comes back to gameplay and I just can't handle it.  I've fought my way through worse games before but theres just something so unappealing to me about this game that I can't go on with it.  But maybe you can, I don't know, this really does seem to be one of those games that people either love or can't make up their minds either way about.  I didn't like it but I can see why some people might, if you want to listen to metal and Jack Black going nuts and aren't bothered by average gameplay then you might get more out of this then me.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												Who is this Game For?==================People who like Heavy Metal, Jack Black and like the idea of it's psdo hybrid RTS, hack'n'slash brawler. Even then, Jack Black and Heavy Metal can only carry this game so far.Is it good?=================It’s a failure. While historically that accusation is because it confusingly turns from a hack’n'slash brawler into an RTS about three hours in, that’s not really the problem here. The issue is that Brütal Legend is an idea in search of a game design. In fact, it’s even more nebulous than that: it’s raw enthusiasm in search of a game design.Does it have any problems?========================Brütal Legend on the PC seems like a huge missed opportunity to really refine the gameplay to make an all-around better game. There could have been quickbars to access powers instead of using a radial menu system, click-to-move mouse support, the ability to select individual units with the right-mouse button, and overall better camera controls and a mini-map. In other words, this could've been much more than a straightforward port. This game is not the best of ports and is riff with plently of problems. I would recommend checking out the PC Wiki before buying.(http://pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Br%C3%BCtal_Legend)Final Thoughts!====================I want to go nuts. I’m just not sure that ropey, weightless buggy-driving, RTS army control that doesn’t go any deeper than essentially Everyone Go Over There and a spectacular open world where you die if you touch water and the only thing to do outside of the storyline is cloned minigames offers me the scope to go nuts that it thinks it does.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												Developer Tim Schafer has been delivering funny games for the past two decades, but none of them have enjoyed the marketing push of Brutal Legend. Gaming's best kept secret has been given the limelight. Has Schafer and his studio Double Fine created something worthy of all this attention?Oh, hell yeah. This is one of the best games I've played all year and it provides something we don't find often enough in this industry: a unique experience. I'm pretty sure you've never played a game quite like this before. True, a game needs to be more than "different" to work -- it has to be fun. And Brutal Legend is a lot of fun.It all kicks off with a hilarious intro poking fun at the softer, more mainstream direction heavy metal has taken in the past couple decades. Brutal Legend is front heavy with the humor stuff, though. While the first half hour will have you shooting milk through your nose, the laughs eventually taper off leaving you with a story that is rich and bizarre but lacking in the bite of the opening scenes. Brutal Legend is a celebration of classic heavy metal and takes every cheap shot it can at hair metal, nu metal, and other diluted variations on the genre. While the ultimate evil and its minions are truly terrible monsters, the lesser bad guys are made up to resemble glam rockers or emo kids. It will appeal most to those that spent at least some of their formative years as angsty headbangers although it isn't exclusionary.Brutal Legend lives up to its name: there is plenty of delightful gore to be found here, although the cartoon art style softens the effect. Heads are chopped off, blood is splattered, and faces melted, but it's all in good fun. The game is rated M for Mature, so theoretically if you're playing you're old enough to appreciate that sort of thing, but regardless you can choose to turn the gore on or off at any time. That might be a handy feature if you have kids that wander into the room from time to time while you're playing. The same can be done with the game's harsh language -- you'll even get the classic Parental Advisory sticker over any middle fingers that are flipped. Not to mention free  DLC for the steam port

content:
Posted: August 3, 2013
												Brütal Legend is a game where you star as Jack Bla- er, Eddie Riggs, a roadie for the worst metal band in history. He longs for the time when metal meant something, where it was hardcore, and worth banging your head to. But these days? People like him are stuck to just being the clean-up crew for today’s “metal." The story starts out with him doing just that, but a part of the stage falls apart, crushing Eddie, causing blood to drip into his belt buckle……Which summons a massive fire beast that brings Eddie to the Brütal Land, which is (as Ben “Yahtzee" Croshaw puts it) a “cross between Narnia and Ozzfest." Brütal Legend features a whole world full of the cliches of the age of metal, from its characters to its styles. Later on in the story, you face off against other factions that represent different sub-genres of rock: glam metal, punk rock, and deathcore. A bit a ways into the game, you find out that the game isn’t just an open-world game with hack’n’slash combat… A lot of missions are also RTS’s (real time strategies). These are called stage battles, where you send units from your stage to go attack enemy units, and tear down their stage. You do a lot of these, but it’s still entertaining to send out Headbangers (troops that spent their whole lives mining by banging their heads, until they all have inhumanly thick necks)  and Metal Beasts (massive, feline beasts that breath fire, tamed by women that look like Amazons, but from KISS) and watch them tear up enemy troops. Eddie Riggs is still often an entertaining character, dishing out lines that would normally seem annoying and a bit childish, but Jack Black delivers them wonderfully.Gameplay wise, the game is subpar. It’s not necessarily bad, but it feels obviously unpolished. Additionally, some features you have to find yourself (such as where to upgrade your weapons/vehicle), the game giving no clue on what/where it is. But the unique setting, entertaining characters, and twisty story make up for it. I’d definitely recommend Brütal Legend.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												As a game, Brutal Legend really is terrible. Yet I have to recommend it. First, the bad: Ill-concieved game mechanics, buggy interface, clunky controls. I have a high tolerance for wierdness --- Giants: Citizen Kabuto is one of my favorite games of all time, and Brutal Legend, to its credit, immediately brought Giants to mind --- so don't take my criticism as coming from someone who wants developers to play it safe. Brutal Legend takes bold chances, and makes bold choices, and fails in almost every respect mechanic-wise. In the last 20 minutes of play, I've driven off a hidden cliff twice, gotten stuck in a polygon once, and, just before writing this review, my game crashed to desktop. Just after this review, however, I'm going right back in. Why? It's because in everything else that Brutal Legend does it does them so well that it's hard to imagine any improvements. Jack Black shines, the soundtrack is excellent, the colorful character designs are really fun. No spoilers: Watch for the first appearance of the a main enemy about five or six story missions in. Back in the day, we'd call this game a "must rent," with all that implies. It simply would not be worth a purchase because of its many flaws, but it does everything else so well that it's worth experiencing. It's the sort of game which would shine on a Let's Play, or in machinima. Simultaneously, it's the sort of game which even if you see all it has to offer, you'll want to send the developer some cash just for the wildness of the ride and the execution of all it does well. Thanks to Steam sales and Humble Bundle packaging, you can pick it up for a few dollars, and it will be a well-spent few dollars.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												First off, yes I do recommend this game, but only to the following people :-Fans of Tim Schafer and previous Double Fine games-Fans of heavy metal musicThat being said Brutal Legend is a hybrid between action/adventure and real time strategy. You play Eddie Riggs (voiced by Jack Black), a roadie who, after an accidental sacrifice of blood, is transported to the land of Metal. It's inhabitants are living in squalor and fear of an oppressive emperor, Doviculus.The journey toward restoring freedom to this land will be filled with many locales, enemies and varied missions. In addition, you will be able to upgrade your car in the motor forges, unearth statues which will unlock new songs to listen to while driving, learn guitar solos that comes with various effects and so on.Pros :-Story and dialogue is top notch-The world is filled with lore and great ideas. The attention given to the details is   exceptionnal-Fans of metal will feel right at home, others might be put off-Songlist is long and covers all the main metal subgenresCons :-Gameplay is underwhelming in every aspects, combat feels tame and upgrades don't seem   to deepened it at all-Anyone who has played at least one mediocre RTS will rage over the RTS elements present   in the gameplay. They are clunky and some basics are not even present-Tad too long-Achievements are mostly grindyFinal :Clearly a labor of love, this game is for fans of Schafer/Double Fine and Metal music (or both such as myself), a shining example of "better than the sum of it's part". Nevertheless if you are not a fan stay clear 8.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Much of the enjoyment of the game is the music selection and orchestration. I have youtube playthroughs of many of the missions (sadly a lot were hit with claims, but w/e) and in putting them together I'm struck by how appropriate the music choices are for the sequences.It's not *just* heavy metal in the soundtrack, but it is all essentially rock. And it's *always* appropriate.The story is well written. Virtually all the stories in Tim Schafer games are excellent. The gameplay can feel repetative because it's not a hardcore brawler or a hardcore RTS or a hardcore pikmin/overlord. It has all of these bits that come together with lots of diverse forms of play. The open world combat spans the gamut from "yeah, I can solo this easy" to "omg run away!" There are small encounter missions with minigames and just out-and-out combat. There's lots of landmarks to find that explain the world and lore.I daresay you can liken it to the GTA/SR games. They're terrible driving games. They're terrible shooters. They're terrible at everything *except* writing and providing a vast world to explore and screw around in. In sum, though, it provides a fun experience.If you actually *hate* rock music, it's possible you have a bad time. Not because the game depends on it, but because Brutal Legend also draws on a lot of the same tropes. The landscapes are out of metal covers from the 70s and 80s. The backstory *is* Metal. I think, though, if you're open enough to playing the game at all, you'll be fine with it.I *love* this game. ffs... I figure out tabs for some of the music from the OST.I think you'll be able to get over your "not a fan"ness of metal and enjoy the game.One last thing, if you love Jack Black, you'll be a bit disappointed, as his character is not as Jack Black as some Jack Blacks you might have seen. If you hate Jack Black, you'll be happy to know that his character is not as Jack Black as some of the Jack Blacks you might have seen.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2013
												Brütal Legend is a game where you star as Jack Bla- er, Eddie Riggs, a roadie for the worst metal band in history. He longs for the time when metal meant something, where it was hardcore, and worth banging your head to. But these days? People like him are stuck to just being the clean-up crew for today’s “metal." The story starts out with him doing just that, but a part of the stage falls apart, crushing Eddie, causing blood to drip into his belt buckle……Which summons a massive fire beast that brings Eddie to the Brütal Land, which is (as Ben “Yahtzee" Croshaw puts it) a “cross between Narnia and Ozzfest." Brütal Legend features a whole world full of the cliches of the age of metal, from its characters to its styles. Later on in the story, you face off against other factions that represent different sub-genres of rock: glam metal, punk rock, and deathcore. A bit a ways into the game, you find out that the game isn’t just an open-world game with hack’n’slash combat… A lot of missions are also RTS’s (real time strategies). These are called stage battles, where you send units from your stage to go attack enemy units, and tear down their stage. You do a lot of these, but it’s still entertaining to send out Headbangers (troops that spent their whole lives mining by banging their heads, until they all have inhumanly thick necks)  and Metal Beasts (massive, feline beasts that breath fire, tamed by women that look like Amazons, but from KISS) and watch them tear up enemy troops. Eddie Riggs is still often an entertaining character, dishing out lines that would normally seem annoying and a bit childish, but Jack Black delivers them wonderfully.Gameplay wise, the game is subpar. It’s not necessarily bad, but it feels obviously unpolished. Additionally, some features you have to find yourself (such as where to upgrade your weapons/vehicle), the game giving no clue on what/where it is. But the unique setting, entertaining characters, and twisty story make up for it. I’d definitely recommend Brütal Legend.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												So this is one of my favorite games of all time.Setting: Imagine a game based on what it would be like to interact and inhabit the world that's depicted on Heavy Metal albums from the 70-80's.Imagine seeing a creature like the one depicted on Judas Priest's 'Screaming for Vengeance' or better yet, to be able to travel to the great pyramid and temples of Iron Maiden's 'Power Slave' album.Only the journey doesn't end there...imagine if this metal world was separated into different regions based on the different styles of music. An example region, Mashlands covered in a dense fog that's the home of emo-nightmare before Christmas creatures and people.Another example, imagine Amazon jungles with panthers that shoot lazers out of their eyes while being road by warrior women from KISS' album 'Love Gun'.Gameplay: The game starts out as a 3rd person hack and slash with driving and overall RPG- Action/Adventure where the hero explore this amazing world I talked about above. You soon assemble an army, from this point you become a commander and a warrior...the game then becomes a RTS. It's a very interesting shift in gameplay.Story:The story honestly reminds of something from a Black Sabbath or RUSH album. I can't put it into words without spoiling it.I think the best way to play this is jump in head first.Soundtrack: One of the greatest soundtracks out there. If you want to cut your teeth on metal, rock, or just something new for those of you who don't normally listen to heavy stuff, look no further. The soundtrack that comes with the game for $19.99 is the OST written for the game (Not the one with Ozzy, Iron Maiden, and so on) . Which I also highly recommend.Does this game have it's issues? of course but, I highly recommend it to anyone and everyone thanks to the game world, music, and it's great story.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												I really, really, REALLY wanted to like this game.  It was an awesome concept that was poorly done.Based off of the trailers I expected a Legend of Zelda meets metal.  Instead I found myself playing a Legend of Zelda meets metal meets Dawn of War meets GTA meets.... well you get the point.  That was of course after I spent hours trying to get it to run properly.This game just lacked direction in what it wanted to be and game play suffers for it.  The combat is meh, the battles have no real strategy, and the car... that piece of s*** CAR!  Driving controls are awful with a bad camera and the majority of the game requires you to drive.  Blasting metal tunes doesn't make it any better (which I do on my way to work in the real world).  If you're in a race and slightly bump into something (which you will cause controls suck) you might as well start over.Some positives is that the world itself is well done.  I think that's the only reason I'm still playing it.  I want to see the sights and learn the lore of world. Its clear the developers put a lot of thought and passion into it.  I get a kick every time I see Ozzy Osbourne as the Guardian of Metal and the cut scenes are also fun to watch.  I can see that they thought it was epic enough to support different genres in one game.  They needed to just stick to one and develop it far enough to add epic game play to this epic world.If you want to check it out, I would wait till its on sale.  When you get mad at it, you wont feel even angrier for paying full price.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												I was never really into rock or metal. Some games had great songs in that genre, but others not so much.This game has mostly awesome songs, and actually got me into this type of music.If you absolutely hate rock and metal and cannot stand to bear it, don't get this game.Anyway, besides the music, the game is very fun. There is comedy in the game, and I honestly don't laugh at many things. I liked a few of the jokes the characters made. Of course I didn't fall out of my chair, but I laughed a little.The story starts with a Roadie named Eddie Riggs who gets killed after an on-stage accident. The statue on the stage comes to life, turning into the God of Metal, full of rage over Eddies death and killed the idiot performers that caused it. He takes Eddie into another world, and Eddie finds himself in a situation where he has to lead a rebellion against ones keeping the locals from having their freedom.I won't say much more. I personally loved the story, and I don't want to spoil it.But if you beat storymode, or don't feel like doing it right way, you can always explore the world to find collectibles, or complete side missions (they can be repetitive, but they give you money for upgrades).The game has a HUGE world. The best way to get around is in your car, and upgrading it's speed and turbo boost would really help you go to far-off places. The scenery is very nice, and you really want to run over the creatures running around.The only issue I have is that foot or car are the only choices for transportation. If there was some sort of teleportation or fast travel, it would've been much better.The gameplay is great. Driving is easy. Controls are simple. Combat is very smooth, and there are a couple of combos that you can use. Also you can pick which weapons you'd use, letting you try out different weapon effects to see what you feel comfortable with.However, my main issue with combat is that it's easy to die on Normal difficulty. I don't bite off more than I can chew (not often, anyway), but when I feel that I can take a couple of enemies, I'm proven wrong.Currently, the only way I know how to increase your maximum health is by finding a bunch of dragon statues, and there are so many placed that it takes about five to ten of them for a tiny bit of health being increased.If you want a noticeable difference, I suggest finding as many statues as you can.Now, the most memorable thing about the game are Stage Battles. Bascially you are able to call and command troops. It's your choice to focus on offense or defense, but a balance of both is very handy.The goal of a Stage Battle is to destroy the enemy's stage. Don't think you can do it yourself while a hundred of your guys distract the enemy; you are unable to harm a stage. And as soon as the stage becomes damaged, an alarm plays, and the enemy immediately rushes to it and tries to stop you.You are also able to fly during a Stage Battle. Flying is the fastest way to travel, and lets you see everything while remaining unharmed. Unfortunately, you are only able to fly during a Stage Battle. If it was available in free-roam, it would've been amazing.Multiplayer lets you have a Stage Battle against another player online. Additionally, it lets you play as two of the enemies you fought against in single-player, along with Eddie's side. Each side has their own ups and downs, different troops with different abilites, and different solos (which are basically player abilities).However, I have never been able to find another player online.But a good thing is that you can play against a bot for practice, and can choose it's difficulty. This isn't exactly the same, I'm sure, but it lets you have a Stage Battle at any time you want.Overall the game is amazing. I loved the gameplay, I loved almost all of the music, and it's definetly worth playing.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I'm not a heavy metal fan and for a long time that kept me from trying Brutal Legend. And that's a shame because - based on heavy metal or not - this as an imaginative and fun game with amazing graphic style and impressive soundwork (both in voice-acting and music). Unfortunately, the actual game portion of this title suffers in comparison, with unimpressive minigames, unfocused gameplay and unwieldy controls. I loved /exploring/ the spectacular world that the developers had created and interacting with its colorful characters, but found the combat, the driving and the platforming to be tedious at best. Sadly, this seems to be par for the course for Doublefine; I loved the settings of both Stacking and Psychonauts but couldn't stand the gameplay of those titles either. Ultimately, I gave up on Brutal Legend long before I reached the end, albeit not without remorse, as the world is that interesting. But I just couldn't take the gameplay anymore.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												I'm going to be brutally honest with you, brutal legend is an amazing with a unique design, fusing music (specifically metal/rock), real time strategy and action-rpg.  The balance is just right, and the world you explore is amazing and detailed, giving you lots of opportunities when you are not progressing the main storyline to explore and take on side tasks if you desire. The game's hero is voiced by Jack Black and he brings his signature humor to the game, coupled with other celebrity appearances lending to the atmosphere of the game. Returning to the gameplay, the combat is almost single hero based with squad control, and basic single base RTS elements which it executes well (very intuitive with controller). The story is something I'd rather not spoil, but it is characteristic of Metal, and Metal themed media, that being said, even if you as the gamer are not a fan of the genre there is still a rich world and character interactions/story elements that are applicable to all aspects of music and a solid gameplay experience which should definitely keep you involved. The only place where this game falls short, and I'm not alone in this sentiment, is near the end (spoiler free review of course), it seems like the game was going to have a decisive third act but instead it was concluded on the second act. Nobody really knows the reasoning behind this aside from probably the development team, but it left gamers wanting more even though it did still basically wrap up all the loose ends of the story. Regardless this game is a full recommendation to fans of metal/rock no all music, and those who enjoy a good action rpg. It is an accessible, quality experience which will leave you with many fond memories of it. Embrace your inner metal-head and get this game.

												Great game but I can't recommend it to anyone.  Don't get me wrong, I love the idea behind this and the game as some really cool mechanics, wicked humor, and is the right mix of RPG and FPS.  However, the camera in this game is annoying as hell.  Basic functions of walking or driving a vehicle will have you believing that you are drunk.  For random reasons, I have yet to figure out, the camera  changes angles indiscrimately and at critical times while trying to do something.  I mean what is the purpose (ever!) to move a camera angle to anything but behind a vehicle when you are driving it?  I don't want to see what I look like in the car, I want to see where I'm going.  Targeting enemies or getting around obstacles is more difficult than it needs to be.  After decades of FPS games on the market, how is it that a developer can screw this basic thing up so badly.  It's sad that one simple thing ruins this game so easily and that it can be easily fixed.  Not going to be playing much of this one unless the camera is patched.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												STORYThe game greets you with a cool intro with Jack Black entering a music store telling you about this secret vynil getting you into the main screen, the game starts fast pasced and the main character is behind scenes of a new hip metal group that arent all that metal and he talks on how real metal is dead, one thing thing leads to another and he gets transported to this metal themed world and gets into an all out war against some guys that want to "sell out".GAMEPLAYThe game starts strongly as a beat em up wich i loved, but as you keep playing there are this sort of battles that resemble more  an RTS than anything else and they get boring REALLY fast, the only thing that keeps you playing are the well written dialoge and interesting characters, though I havent beaten the game to say if the whole game is like this.GRAPHICSGraphically the ame is not very appeling, with aweful hair physics and outdated textures wich resembles more something that came from the original xbox than the new gen.The overworld is as plain as it can get, good thing you get a car early into the game or it would take years to get to point A to point B, also I dont know if it is just me but the animations seem to have been done to be played at 30 fps, and so i am playing at 60 fps and it looks like if im am looking at a claymation, but as I said, it could just be me.SOUNDProbably the best thing about the game, it got some great voice acting, including Black Jack as the protagonist and Ozzy Osbourne as our car seller wich got some HILARIOUS quotes, also the game comes with a killer soundtrack with copyrighted metal songs and some other original ones. The dialoge is one of the funniest I have seen in a while aswell.CONCLUSIONI havent played the whole game but for what i have played is not worth the the full price, sure the writting and characters are spot on, but they alone dont sell the game for me, if you are getting it try to get it on a sale since it is still worth a whirl, how ever it isnt a must buy.

Posted: April 2, 2014
												The concept for this game is an inspired work of genius but I can't bring myself to recommend this game. You play as Jack Black who is sucked into a world of heavy metal and demons. World awesome and full of cool characters and cameos from heavy metal legends. The problem comes with the gameplay. It has elements of hack and slash, real time strategy, free roaming exploration and driving. It manages to do all of these elements quite badly. The hack and slash parts are okay, the RTS parts are terrible, the side missions are uninspired and repetitive, the mapping system is poor, The inability to jump and the sketchy driving make getting around annoying, the upgrades seem to make no appreciable difference and the story is for the most part uninteresting. I guess if you like heavy metal you'd like the sound track but once I had turned off all the songs I didn't like I was basically left listening to Mr Crowley on repeat. This game does have its moments but mostly it is just not that much fun.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I would love to rate this game higher, but I am affraid I can not. The question of course is why, because the game certainly does have several things that speak for it. Brutal Legend is a game filled with humor that is akin to main man's introduction cult movie; The Pick of Destiny. Personally, I enjoy it for in the game it is not constantly bombarded at you if you are just cruising in the Druid Plow (that is your car), but fills the conversations with a light air that is certainly good for a laugh. If you are cruising Metal music (of different genres of metal) greets your ears. Something I enjoy and in fact made me appreciate some artists better, but certainly not for everyone. Okay so that gives it a rather niche public, but that doesn't make it bad does it? No, it doesn't.However, the game also has real time combat and does so in a the old Warcraft/Starcraft format, but has the view not topdown but on you as well as you are a important player. With no pause function, bad overview, the fact that you need to fight as well as command constantly -  because the AI is just horrible - makes it stressful. A shrill constrast to the rest. Now a friend of mine has it and does well enough. The difference, a controller. I have mouse and keyboard and the controls are such .... finicky, that on a dial I can not even select the unit above or below it because it either won't move or will go down 2 in an instance. The solos you need to perform to boost you army also require key combinations which also go wrong at times due to this. No problem outside combat but in it... The problem is that this game is fun, looks nicely, has good humor, but was not properly developed for combat with mouse and keyboard.Thus, the game has its niche in which it does well. However, if you do not like this niche or do not own a controller, I would say it is not worth the frustation of the combat and quirky controls (even with remapping!) - because that is the opposite of what the game is intended to be and would be a dissappointment over an otherwise well intended and decently executed (mainly music, humor and graphic wise) game.

												Brütal legend is a heavy metal themed hack'n slash open world racing game. You play as Eddie Riggs who become the leader of Ironheade after having freed them by starting a revolution. Eddie's main enemy is the boss demon named Dovicolous. On the tour we have lot of stage battles against demons, and we can recriute fans to our side. Many collcetibles are scattered around to find, and there are also secondary missions, too. Completeing primary and secondary quests as well as helping your buddies to defeat enemies you gain fire tributes that is used as a "currency" to buy upgrades for yourself and your vehicle called Deuce. Deuce can be summoned everywhere after playing a giutar solo. Giutar solos results in cool things such as battly cry, summoning a burning airship which crashes to your enemies causing serious damage to them etc. And finally you can always hear heavy metal music for example from Motörhead. I really enjoyed playing it. 7,5/10

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												There's a lot to like here.  The graphics and audio are well-done, the whole heavy metal asthetic is burned into the DNA of the game and its world and there are lots of great heavy metal tracks to unlock from a really well-chosen selection of big-name bands and more obscure (but excellent) underground bands.  The characters are okay, not up to the typical Double Fine standard of memorability or amusingness, but most voice acting is great (the worst being the guest voices from rock icons, but hey, it's authentic) and it's mostly lighthearted enough.What really fails is the game itself.  There's some moderate fun to be had driving around and exploring. but the riff-based 'magic' system isn't as fun as it should be, and the pivotal epic battles are designed as (bizarrely) a sort of real-time strategy game that is clumsy, confusing, and ultimately so damn poor.  The story - a fairly generic tale of good, evil, betrayal and redemption - is merely a skeleton to dress the rest of the game upon, and not enough to keep me playing through an indefinite number of these rough spots.

												I loved the humor and the silly over the top heavy metal universe, that's a lot of fun for the first couple of hours. Unfortunately I can't really recommend this game.Its gameplay is an hybrid of RTS and 3rd person action/adventure. And like most hybrid games, it does neither very well. Having to fight the interface to try to give your army orders is not very fun.Not even the awesome soundtrack manages to save this game for me. As a real action/adventure game or maybe even as a regular RTS with decent controls it might have been a great game. On the other hand if you like weird hybrids and don't mind using "consolized" controls to play a RTS game then you may still like it.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This game: so much potential wasted by ignoring the details. The characters, story, and acting are pretty good. But it makes me wonder how it would have been without Jack Black. Probably not as good! But the real thing lacking in this title is the gameplay. First of all; there is no JUMP. It LOOKS like an action-adventure/platformer, but it's just the action adventure part. Sure it is my own pre-conceived notions that expect a JUMP function but I'm sorry, I LOVE jumping in games. You no have jump, you no have fun game. In context, of course. I don't expect jumping in Civ 5. I digress...Overall the controls are just plain clunky and not responsive enough. The attack moves are more funny than practical. You will likely figure out the two moves you like and stick mainly with those along with the block move. The kicker is that the camera control is sub-par. I suppose perfect camera in 3rd person is rare.If you can get it on a sale or bundle, it's probably worth it just for the humor, especially if you're a rocker, otherwise I do not recommend this game.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												"Full Controller Support" Does it hell! Controls are slow and sluggish at best.I'm not trying to use anything fancy, nothing with 76 buttons, 3 ergonomically crafted sticks, light-up, flood-proof, shock-proof, proof-proof(!), titanium cased with twiddly-bits... No! (not that I can afford anything remotely resembling AlienWare anyway.)All I want to use is a standard issue wired xbox 360 controller!!! I can use it with Fez, Gateways, Jamestown and loads of other 'small' games, so why not BL? Not being insulting but I am comparing those mentioned with a game that has had enough money to afford Jack Black and Lemmy thrown at it. What the chuffing hell is going on? Occassionally the buttons work in BL, the triggers don't at all. The controls are sluggish and sloppy, reacting split seconds behind the press.Okay, I'm playing on a laptop, HP DV7, 6gb ram, i5-2410M cpu (@2.3gHz), Radeon HD 6490M gfx (512 dedicated ram) so I shouldn't expect a lot.... But, I own and have played Arkham Asylum, Arkham City, and Saint's Row 3 fluidly with no lag and completed them all, so I honestly don't think it's too much to expect to have something like responsive and working controls as a standard feature!I can only say that I'm glad it came as part of a Humble Bundle so I can write it off against the other better games that came with it. I'd be a lot more disappointed if I'd paid full money for this. I also find it disappointing given that the same company released Psychonauts, a great game that contrary to BL I'd recommend at the drop of a hat.

												This is quite possibly the worst game I have ever played and I've played a lot, the story is weak to a degree that a 10 year old child wrote it. You are left with more questions at the end than actual answers to this vast new society that you are chucked into. Character backgrounds are a big let down as there is ZERO mentioning about them so really you learn nothing apart from HEAVY METALLL!!!!!!!!Characters will drive you insane after a few hours that you will want to tear your own ears off so you don't have to listen to the same sentence when doing a side mission, over and over and over and over and over and over.... Control's are awkward when trying to play stratergist on the battlefield and it gets old really quickly. Eventually you will be forced to reduce the difficulty level as the enemy side are (one hitting) your troops that it becomes more of a torture than any sort of enjoyment.Maybe they should of paid Jack Black less and actually hired a decent developer + producer and a wider range of voice actors the game probably would actually be pretty good unlike this rubbish before us! How they ever won an award is nothing short of laughable stupidity! IGN gave it a 9.0/10 seems to me they never actually played it...  it's a 3/10 at best in my opinion, so instead spend £1 on getting super Hexagon or something with a beer, as that is much more fun.I laugh at anybody who ever paid full price for this garbage, I got this at a deal price and felt they should have paid me in the end... worst purchase on steam BY FAR!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												The Good:- A Double Fine Production means lots of good humor in the game- Apearance and voice of some Metal Gods Like Ozzy Osbourne- Nice Selection of Metal Music- Good dialogues between charracters inside primary missionsThe Bad:- This game can be the example of poor level design. It's one of the worst in gaming history!- Bad collider implementing for objects and environment- Very poor physics engine (after an accident no one can guess which direction your car will go!)- Car Control is a true headache (it's very hard to control your car and driving will cause motion sickness in this game)- Side missions are boring and repeatative- The strategy part of the game isn't fun at all (I wish it had gameplay like Darksiders or GoW or Devil May Cry)The Ugly:- The worst part of the game is driving (like I said in the bad part it's really really bad). And the ugly part is that this is an open world game, which means you have to use the car a lot, and experience lots of accidents with objects and animals, falling into oceans and abysses and headache from motion sickness (and I used a Xbox360 controller, god help who uses mouse and keyboard!!!). Actually when I think about it I'm so relieved that I will never play the game again.With all that I just said I'm sure that I probably can't stop you from spending 1.5$ (in 90% off) over this game, like I couldn't stop myself from buying it. But please for god's sake DO NOT spend too much time on side missions and finding collectibles and make the game 100% complete like I did. Just play the Primary missions, watch game's ending and uninstall it.[P.S. you can still play and make the game 100% after completing campain, but this time you can save a lot of time with the car upgrade that'll show you map secrets.]

content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												Oh how I am loath to say something negative about Double Fine.  It's a company I would love to support, but this is the end.  As usual, they're amazing at building a world, characters are good, funny etc, but gameplay is perplexingly bad.  It's like they come up with the story and plot, then outsource the gameplay to some chimps who've only played about three games before and mash them all together.  I can't explain how such a mess of a game could get released otherwise.  The game is part strategy, part RPG, part Adventure.  The strategy is overly simplistic, just hurl your units at the others and give them a hand... yet you have a big ♥♥♥♥ off axe that still takes 6 hits to take out the weakest enemy.  So when there's 30 enemy, that's a lot of chopping... using your area attacks are just as weak, but they might hit three enemy at once, still takes 6 hits minimum though.The adventure part takes place in the worst sandbox I have ever encountered.  It's what I would call 'over designed'  everything looks so dense that it looks the same, so navigating is tiresome, difficult at times, and worst of all, boring.What's worse, when you spend 20 minutes. 20 sodding ♥♥♥♥ing minutes driving around, not even doing missions, simply going from one place to the next mission, getting stuck, fighting random hordes of enemies, only to make it all the way to your next mission, just nick a bit of black ground that looks the same as the rest of all the other black ground, but apparantly it was black water, which is instant death, only to get respawned WAY on the other side of the map and have to do it all again... you're♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off... When I made it back once more, I Saved it as I didn't want to start the next mission as it was now time to go and do something else as all of my time was wasted, when returning, it loaded me WAY on the other side of the ♥♥♥♥ing map again, and I had to drive all the way back.. again....Oh, and many parts of the map are identical, they just changed the colour filter, clever in its use, but lazy is lazy... OHx2, bugged up the♥♥♥♥♥♥at times, game breakingly so, only twice, but still.Lastly, and fatally.  In a game you drive a great deal, the driving mechanics are the worst I've seen in a Sandbox, and I've seen some BAD driving mechanics.So in summary, ONLY buy this if you are VERY forgiving of bad gameplay because you enjoy fun characters and settings etc, and if you are a big big fan of Double fine games... I was... this is the end my friend, never again.It's a shame, with a bit more polish it could have been a c+ as it is, it's a big AVOID!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												I purchased this game as part of the Humble Double Fine Bundle, so use that tint when reading this review.Brutal Legend has oodles of theme, but can't quite decide what it wants for gameplay, and suffers accordingly.  You start out with your typical hack'n'slash, then it adds a driving element, and just when you are getting comfortable with that, you find that the major encounters are handled as real-time strategy battles.  There were a number of issues that really hurt my opinion of the game:The driving implementation is terrible.  You simply cannot steer effectivelyThe camera is only taking your suggestion.  Sometimes it is completely out of your controlThe overview map is too vagueThe directional hints via the turn signals are too difficult to useDetermining your health is a guessing gameSame for your vehicle health, enemy health, boss healthSide quest variety is extremely limitedSpecial combos do not fire reliablyI set the game to normal difficulty and expected a fair challenge.  Instead, I found in some scenarios I could do nothing at all and succeed, and in others I had to figure out a precise series of RTS actions to lead to victory.  In some of the ambushes your party rushes off to death before you can even get under way.  On the upside, Brutal Legend features an amazing soundtrack and voice cast.  If you love heavy metal you might enjoy this game on theme alone.  In fact, you'll probably forgive all of it's blemishes for having Lemmy, Ozzy, Jack Black, Lita Ford, and many more.  I'm not a huge metal fan, though, so for all of its charm I just couldn't get past the glaring gameplay issues.

												This game kicks all sorts of♥♥♥♥♥ I really can't believe I haven't heard of it until relatively recently and only played it today. It's almost like a parasite of a company (that to this day continues to be funded by mouthbreathing idiots like those that plague Steam) sabotaged its marketing because of something as silly as genre fads and stopped the company behind it from doing anything otherwise interesting like porting it. Funny that.Anyway, I haven't played much of it thus far (am actually redoing the first part because it's that awesome) but I think I've played enough to get a decent idea of the gameplay. It's kind of like a more fluid ARTS mixed with third person fighting. You've got two axes. One is an actual axe for primary attacks and the other a guitar for secondary/ranged/special attacks. It works well thus far and I'm liking how well they did on making it work with a keyboard and mouse. I know that being the type of game this is it should have been PC first anyway but one can't take these things for granted.Besides the gameplay the main thing that made me decide to do the review now instead of later is the epic everything-that-isn't-gameplay. Starting from getting to play someone voiced by Jack Black who is... Well, Jack Black. The art is great and appropriately metal with some pretty awesome character and world design. The advertising really isn't lying when they say it's inspired by rock album covers. Speaking of, the music in this just kicks all sorts of♥♥♥♥♥too. I don't even know what else to say besides that. Seriously... Just look on youtube for the OST. No description does it justice.I'm also liking the story. It glorifies everything epic about rock while at the same time taking loving stabs at the more silly parts of it. In standard Double Fine manner it also likes to point out the obvious while still making it genuinely amusing. One thing that was really weird to me though is that the band who Eddy is a roadie for has a guitarist that is Raz. Not someone who looks like him. He is Raz. I'm guessing it's just because the VA voices both of them and has a distinct voice but in my mind he's an alternate reality Raz who still left the circus but decided to start a garage band (called Psychonauts, it totally works as a band name) instead of going to camp.Anyway, not much else to say yet and I don't really think there is much else to say. It's an epic ARTS-like game with great soundtrack and dialog. If you like ARTS-like games and like great soundtracks I don't imagine you'll be disappointed.Edit: Oh god, I just saw the beginning cutscene again. That's definitely Raz. He's doing the stupid egyptian-walk-dance-thing. :|

												I really like metal. This is a game that lets me fight demons alongside Rob Halford, Lita Ford, and Lemmy. While driving a car that shoots missiles. And Manowar is playing. I think my beard just became fuller from writing that. I also like Double Fine, and I found Brutal Legend to be another hit in their long list of good games. Honestly, I'd probably recommend the game based on the soundtrack alone, which includes over 100 kickass metal tunes to blast while driving around, but like I said, it also has the "being a good game" thing going for it. The strategy elements could have been handled better. It's less "strategically place units" and more "gather troops and throw them at enemies."  Except for the last two bosses, but that's because the computer cheats, and I won't hear anyone say otherwise. There's a lot to explore and find within the game. Lore, solos, songs, dragon statues tied up in bondage gear, and plenty of side missions. Each of these gets you favor with the metal gods, which you can spend on upgrades by talking to the Guardian of Metal, voiced and modeled on Ozzy Osbourne. You can also run over porcupines and ride mammoths into battle. Best of all, you can continue exploring after the main story, so you're not in a rush to finish everything before the end. That's pretty nice. All in all, I had fun, and any game with Iced Earth in their soundtrack gets a recommendation from me. \m/

Posted: January 28, 2015
												This game has pretty much everything a great game should; great music, fun gameplay, interesting characters. However where the game falls short is the campaign. You see, Brutal Legend was designed with the multiplayer component in mind (despite having broken matchmaking), which means the focus of the game is the stage battle system. The story mode clocks in at four hours, is poorely designed and rushed, littered with unlockables, but otherwise worth playing through atleast once. What many players seemed to want was just the hack and slash gameplay, but didn't like the stage battles which were essentially just giving you allies and resource points to fight over. Ironically, everybody loves Dawn of War and Company of Heroes yet didn't like Brutal Legend just because you are on the feild yourself. It's litterally the same concept: Grab the resource points and balance between tech advancements and troop production. In fact, DoW2's MP can be thought of as the RTS only version of Brutal Legends MPGameplay wise, amazing. Your Stage has defenses and produces troops, and can level up to three. You use your troops to clear Fan Geysers so that you can play a magical guitar solo to build a gathering structure on it. You need to have more of these than your enemy to win; as you will get more resources and thus have more troops of better quality. Your goal is to destroy the enemy Stage with your troopers. Map control is required. Another strange thing is the cars, each character has one, but can also fly. It's rare to need such a device if you can fly. It's mostly only for the campaign.

content:
Posted: April 10
												Driving mechanics killed a good game.I would really like to give this game a recommendation, because it's charming, funny, has a lot of heart and I love Double Fine. I would be willing to forgive it it's boring fighting mechanic and pretty empty strategy mechanic (which doesn't have any real strategy to it). If this game only required you to complete one of these two chores (or a less bad "guitar solo" mini game) every now and then to move on to the next funny scene, I would give it 3 stars because that would be an overall fun experience. Jack Black and all his guest stars are just that fun, story is funny and the graphics are very pretty.Sadly, there is also driving. Terrible, TERRIBLE driving.Don't trust the other reviews when they describe driving as "not great". Driving a Yugo is "not great". Driving in this game leaves the impression that it has been designed by a race of ethereal beings from a non-physical plane of existence who tried and failed to imagine the experience of driving based on reading comics and studying photographs. Your car has no inertia and steering...I honestly never had a RL or virtual experience that is comparable to this steering. The closest thing that I can imagine would be driving a tank with super-traction tires on Jupiter. There are few missions that try to spice up the driving with shooting, but the aiming and shooting is, out of necessity, made very easy because keeping the car on course is challenge enough, unless that course is a straight line.I finally quit the game when a mission (won't spoil the story with background) required me to use the to escape a pursuer. There was couple of U turns on the track and...I just don't know. Maybe one of those genius kids who figure out surgery on their own at the age of 6, without ever going to school, maybe one of them could figure out how to complete a semi-challenging driving course in this game without their hearts overflowing with hate and despair. I couldn't, so I had to quit and delete the game without completing it.

You have up to two sides fighting with each other for control of mana- I mean, FAN fountains to destroy your oponent's Altar- I mean the SCENE. Your small armies are controlled via simple commands and supported by your main hero with spells- I mean the SOLOS. It's a great concept really, and Sacrifice pulled it off perectly, of course.The problem with Brutal Legend is that the devs had not a slightest idea how to build this kind of game. That's probably the reason they decided to cover it up with tons of autistic non-content, but I will get to that in a minute.The core gameplay is over-simplified and absurdly unbalanced. You don't have to do any real resource management (your fans are generating only from the fan booths, there are no real base mana units) and from a variety of units, only few are relevant (among all three armies). And even they don't matter, since you have absolutely overpowered guitar solos who can destroy everything around you after a short QTE. It's decent enough for a few fights, but after you discover that the best way is to bait all your enemies into one spot and cast one AoE attack which will take all of them, there's suddenly no challenge, even vs the highest difficulty level. The multiplayer is dead anyway. But all of above is just a small fraction of the whole game. There are up to 8 (?) stage battles throughout the whole game, which is laughable. The rest of the game consists of autism simulating in an open world area, searching for autism throphies and doing lazy side-quests, while struggling with hell of a driving model and collision issues. There's nothing to add about this part of the game, but at the same time it makes up to 90% of it. The theme is amazing, but if you want to listen to some music, just open up your Internet browser. If it's this kind of core gameplay you're looking for, just play Sacrifice. This game is not worth it, unfortunately.
